speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: PROLOGUE

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Two households, both alike in dignity,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: In fair Verona, where we lay our scene,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: From ancient grudge break to new mutiny,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Where civil blood makes civil hands unclean.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: From forth the fatal loins of these two foes

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: A pair of star-cross'd lovers take their life;

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Whose misadventured piteous overthrows

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Do with their death bury their parents' strife.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: The fearful passage of their death-mark'd love,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: And the continuance of their parents' rage,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Which, but their children's end, nought could remove,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Is now the two hours' traffic of our stage;

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: The which if you with patient ears attend,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: What here shall miss, our toil shall strive to mend.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: SCENE I. Verona. A public place.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Enter SAMPSON and GREGORY, of the house of Capulet, armed with swords and bucklers

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Gregory, o' my word, we'll not carry coals.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: No, for then we should be colliers.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: I mean, an we be in choler, we'll draw.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: Ay, while you live, draw your neck out o' the collar.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: I strike quickly, being moved.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: But thou art not quickly moved to strike.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: A dog of the house of Montague moves me.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: To move is to stir; and to be valiant is to stand:

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: therefore, if thou art moved, thou runn'st away.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: A dog of that house shall move me to stand: I will

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: take the wall of any man or maid of Montague's.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: That shows thee a weak slave; for the weakest goes

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: to the wall.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: True; and therefore women, being the weaker vessels,

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: are ever thrust to the wall: therefore I will push

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Montague's men from the wall, and thrust his maids

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: to the wall.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: The quarrel is between our masters and us their men.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: 'Tis all one, I will show myself a tyrant: when I

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: have fought with the men, I will be cruel with the

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: maids, and cut off their heads.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: The heads of the maids?

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads;

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: take it in what sense thou wilt.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: They must take it in sense that feel it.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Me they shall feel while I am able to stand: and

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: 'tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: 'Tis well thou art not fish; if thou hadst, thou

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: hadst been poor John. Draw thy tool! here comes

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: two of the house of the Montagues.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: My naked weapon is out: quarrel, I will back thee.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: How! turn thy back and run?

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Fear me not.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: No, marry; I fear thee!

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Let us take the law of our sides; let them begin.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it as

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: they list.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Nay, as they dare. I will bite my thumb at them;

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: which is a disgrace to them, if they bear it.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Enter ABRAHAM and BALTHASAR

speaker: ABRAHAM
text_entry: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: I do bite my thumb, sir.

speaker: ABRAHAM
text_entry: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: [Aside to GREGORY]  Is the law of our side, if I say

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: ay?

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: No.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: No, sir, I do not bite my thumb at you, sir, but I

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: bite my thumb, sir.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: Do you quarrel, sir?

speaker: ABRAHAM
text_entry: Quarrel sir! no, sir.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: If you do, sir, I am for you: I serve as good a man as you.

speaker: ABRAHAM
text_entry: No better.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Well, sir.

speaker: GREGORY
text_entry: Say 'better:' here comes one of my master's kinsmen.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Yes, better, sir.

speaker: ABRAHAM
text_entry: You lie.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Draw, if you be men. Gregory, remember thy swashing blow.

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: They fight

speaker: SAMPSON
text_entry: Enter BENVOLIO

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Part, fools!

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Put up your swords; you know not what you do.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Beats down their swords

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Enter TYBALT

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds?

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Turn thee, Benvolio, look upon thy death.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: I do but keep the peace: put up thy sword,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Or manage it to part these men with me.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: What, drawn, and talk of peace! I hate the word,

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee:

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Have at thee, coward!

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: They fight

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Enter, several of both houses, who join the fray; then enter Citizens, with clubs

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Clubs, bills, and partisans! strike! beat them down!

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Down with the Capulets! down with the Montagues!

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Enter CAPULET in his gown, and LADY CAPULET

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: What noise is this? Give me my long sword, ho!

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: A crutch, a crutch! why call you for a sword?

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: My sword, I say! Old Montague is come,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And flourishes his blade in spite of me.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Enter MONTAGUE and LADY MONTAGUE

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Thou villain Capulet,--Hold me not, let me go.

speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
text_entry: Thou shalt not stir a foot to seek a foe.

speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
text_entry: Enter PRINCE, with Attendants

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Profaners of this neighbour-stained steel,--

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Will they not hear? What, ho! you men, you beasts,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: That quench the fire of your pernicious rage

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: With purple fountains issuing from your veins,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: On pain of torture, from those bloody hands

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Throw your mistemper'd weapons to the ground,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: And hear the sentence of your moved prince.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Three civil brawls, bred of an airy word,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: By thee, old Capulet, and Montague,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Have thrice disturb'd the quiet of our streets,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: And made Verona's ancient citizens

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Cast by their grave beseeming ornaments,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: To wield old partisans, in hands as old,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Canker'd with peace, to part your canker'd hate:

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: If ever you disturb our streets again,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: For this time, all the rest depart away:

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: You Capulet; shall go along with me:

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: And, Montague, come you this afternoon,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: To know our further pleasure in this case,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: To old Free-town, our common judgment-place.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Once more, on pain of death, all men depart.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Exeunt all but MONTAGUE, LADY MONTAGUE, and BENVOLIO

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach?

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Speak, nephew, were you by when it began?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Here were the servants of your adversary,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And yours, close fighting ere I did approach:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: I drew to part them: in the instant came

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: The fiery Tybalt, with his sword prepared,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Which, as he breathed defiance to my ears,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: He swung about his head and cut the winds,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Who nothing hurt withal hiss'd him in scorn:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: While we were interchanging thrusts and blows,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Came more and more and fought on part and part,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Till the prince came, who parted either part.

speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
text_entry: O, where is Romeo? saw you him to-day?

speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
text_entry: Right glad I am he was not at this fray.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Madam, an hour before the worshipp'd sun

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Peer'd forth the golden window of the east,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: A troubled mind drave me to walk abroad;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Where, underneath the grove of sycamore

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: That westward rooteth from the city's side,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: So early walking did I see your son:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Towards him I made, but he was ware of me

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And stole into the covert of the wood:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: I, measuring his affections by my own,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: That most are busied when they're most alone,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Pursued my humour not pursuing his,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And gladly shunn'd who gladly fled from me.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Many a morning hath he there been seen,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: With tears augmenting the fresh morning dew.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs;

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: But all so soon as the all-cheering sun

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Should in the furthest east begin to draw

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: The shady curtains from Aurora's bed,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Away from the light steals home my heavy son,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: And private in his chamber pens himself,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Shuts up his windows, locks far daylight out

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: And makes himself an artificial night:

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Black and portentous must this humour prove,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Unless good counsel may the cause remove.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: My noble uncle, do you know the cause?

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: I neither know it nor can learn of him.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Have you importuned him by any means?

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Both by myself and many other friends:

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: But he, his own affections' counsellor,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Is to himself--I will not say how true--

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: But to himself so secret and so close,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: So far from sounding and discovery,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: As is the bud bit with an envious worm,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Ere he can spread his sweet leaves to the air,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Or dedicate his beauty to the sun.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: We would as willingly give cure as know.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Enter ROMEO

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: See, where he comes: so please you, step aside;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: I'll know his grievance, or be much denied.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: I would thou wert so happy by thy stay,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: To hear true shrift. Come, madam, let's away.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Exeunt MONTAGUE and LADY MONTAGUE

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Good-morrow, cousin.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Is the day so young?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: But new struck nine.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Ay me! sad hours seem long.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Was that my father that went hence so fast?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: It was. What sadness lengthens Romeo's hours?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Not having that, which, having, makes them short.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: In love?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Out--

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Of love?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Out of her favour, where I am in love.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Alas, that love, so gentle in his view,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Alas, that love, whose view is muffled still,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Should, without eyes, see pathways to his will!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Where shall we dine? O me! What fray was here?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Yet tell me not, for I have heard it all.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Here's much to do with hate, but more with love.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Why, then, O brawling love! O loving hate!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O any thing, of nothing first create!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O heavy lightness! serious vanity!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Mis-shapen chaos of well-seeming forms!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: sick health!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Still-waking sleep, that is not what it is!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: This love feel I, that feel no love in this.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Dost thou not laugh?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: No, coz, I rather weep.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Good heart, at what?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: At thy good heart's oppression.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Why, such is love's transgression.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Which thou wilt propagate, to have it prest

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: With more of thine: this love that thou hast shown

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Doth add more grief to too much of mine own.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Love is a smoke raised with the fume of sighs;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Being purged, a fire sparkling in lovers' eyes;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Being vex'd a sea nourish'd with lovers' tears:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What is it else? a madness most discreet,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: A choking gall and a preserving sweet.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Farewell, my coz.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Soft! I will go along;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: An if you leave me so, you do me wrong.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Tut, I have lost myself; I am not here;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: This is not Romeo, he's some other where.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Tell me in sadness, who is that you love.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What, shall I groan and tell thee?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Groan! why, no.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: But sadly tell me who.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Bid a sick man in sadness make his will:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Ah, word ill urged to one that is so ill!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: I aim'd so near, when I supposed you loved.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: A right good mark-man! And she's fair I love.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Well, in that hit you miss: she'll not be hit

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: With Cupid's arrow; she hath Dian's wit;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And, in strong proof of chastity well arm'd,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: From love's weak childish bow she lives unharm'd.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: She will not stay the siege of loving terms,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Nor bide the encounter of assailing eyes,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O, she is rich in beauty, only poor,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: That when she dies with beauty dies her store.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Then she hath sworn that she will still live chaste?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: For beauty starved with her severity

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Cuts beauty off from all posterity.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: To merit bliss by making me despair:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Do I live dead that live to tell it now.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Be ruled by me, forget to think of her.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O, teach me how I should forget to think.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: By giving liberty unto thine eyes;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Examine other beauties.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: 'Tis the way

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: To call hers exquisite, in question more:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Being black put us in mind they hide the fair;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: He that is strucken blind cannot forget

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: The precious treasure of his eyesight lost:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Show me a mistress that is passing fair,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What doth her beauty serve, but as a note

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Where I may read who pass'd that passing fair?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Farewell: thou canst not teach me to forget.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: I'll pay that doctrine, or else die in debt.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: SCENE II. A street.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Enter CAPULET, PARIS, and Servant

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: But Montague is bound as well as I,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: In penalty alike; and 'tis not hard, I think,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: For men so old as we to keep the peace.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Of honourable reckoning are you both;

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: And pity 'tis you lived at odds so long.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: But now, my lord, what say you to my suit?

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: But saying o'er what I have said before:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: My child is yet a stranger in the world;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: She hath not seen the change of fourteen years,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Let two more summers wither in their pride,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Younger than she are happy mothers made.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And too soon marr'd are those so early made.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: The earth hath swallow'd all my hopes but she,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: She is the hopeful lady of my earth:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: My will to her consent is but a part;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: An she agree, within her scope of choice

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Lies my consent and fair according voice.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: This night I hold an old accustom'd feast,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Whereto I have invited many a guest,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Such as I love; and you, among the store,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: One more, most welcome, makes my number more.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: At my poor house look to behold this night

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Earth-treading stars that make dark heaven light:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Such comfort as do lusty young men feel

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: When well-apparell'd April on the heel

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Of limping winter treads, even such delight

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Among fresh female buds shall you this night

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Inherit at my house; hear all, all see,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And like her most whose merit most shall be:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Which on more view, of many mine being one

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: May stand in number, though in reckoning none,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Come, go with me.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: To Servant, giving a paper

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Go, sirrah, trudge about

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Through fair Verona; find those persons out

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Whose names are written there, and to them say,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: My house and welcome on their pleasure stay.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Exeunt CAPULET and PARIS

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Find them out whose names are written here! It is

speaker: Servant
text_entry: written, that the shoemaker should meddle with his

speaker: Servant
text_entry: yard, and the tailor with his last, the fisher with

speaker: Servant
text_entry: his pencil, and the painter with his nets; but I am

speaker: Servant
text_entry: sent to find those persons whose names are here

speaker: Servant
text_entry: writ, and can never find what names the writing

speaker: Servant
text_entry: person hath here writ. I must to the learned.--In good time.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Enter BENVOLIO and ROMEO

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Tut, man, one fire burns out another's burning,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: One pain is lessen'd by another's anguish;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Turn giddy, and be holp by backward turning;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: One desperate grief cures with another's languish:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Take thou some new infection to thy eye,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And the rank poison of the old will die.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Your plaintain-leaf is excellent for that.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: For what, I pray thee?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: For your broken shin.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Why, Romeo, art thou mad?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Not mad, but bound more than a mad-man is;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Shut up in prison, kept without my food,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Whipp'd and tormented and--God-den, good fellow.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: God gi' god-den. I pray, sir, can you read?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Ay, mine own fortune in my misery.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Perhaps you have learned it without book: but, I

speaker: Servant
text_entry: pray, can you read any thing you see?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Ay, if I know the letters and the language.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Ye say honestly: rest you merry!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Stay, fellow; I can read.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Reads

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: 'Signior Martino and his wife and daughters;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: County Anselme and his beauteous sisters; the lady

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: widow of Vitravio; Signior Placentio and his lovely

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: nieces; Mercutio and his brother Valentine; mine

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: uncle Capulet, his wife and daughters; my fair niece

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Rosaline; Livia; Signior Valentio and his cousin

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Tybalt, Lucio and the lively Helena.' A fair

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: assembly: whither should they come?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Up.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Whither?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: To supper; to our house.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Whose house?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: My master's.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Indeed, I should have ask'd you that before.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Now I'll tell you without asking: my master is the

speaker: Servant
text_entry: great rich Capulet; and if you be not of the house

speaker: Servant
text_entry: of Montagues, I pray, come and crush a cup of wine.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Rest you merry!

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: At this same ancient feast of Capulet's

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so lovest,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: With all the admired beauties of Verona:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Go thither; and, with unattainted eye,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Compare her face with some that I shall show,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: When the devout religion of mine eye

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Maintains such falsehood, then turn tears to fires;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And these, who often drown'd could never die,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Transparent heretics, be burnt for liars!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: One fairer than my love! the all-seeing sun

text_entry: Ne'er saw her match since first the world begun.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Tut, you saw her fair, none else being by,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Herself poised with herself in either eye:

text_entry: But in that crystal scales let there be weigh'd

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Your lady's love against some other maid

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: That I will show you shining at this feast,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And she shall scant show well that now shows best.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I'll go along, no such sight to be shown,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: But to rejoice in splendor of mine own.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: SCENE III. A room in Capulet's house.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Enter LADY CAPULET and Nurse

speaker: LADY CAPULET

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: I have remember'd me, thou's hear our counsel.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Thou know'st my daughter's of a pretty age.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Faith, I can tell her age unto an hour.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: She's not fourteen.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I'll lay fourteen of my teeth,--

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: And yet, to my teeth be it spoken, I have but four--

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: She is not fourteen. How long is it now

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: To Lammas-tide?

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: A fortnight and odd days.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Even or odd, of all days in the year,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Come Lammas-eve at night shall she be fourteen.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Susan and she--God rest all Christian souls!--

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Were of an age: well, Susan is with God;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: She was too good for me: but, as I said,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: On Lammas-eve at night shall she be fourteen;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: That shall she, marry; I remember it well.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: 'Tis since the earthquake now eleven years;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: And she was wean'd,--I never shall forget it,--

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Of all the days of the year, upon that day:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: For I had then laid wormwood to my dug,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Sitting in the sun under the dove-house wall;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: My lord and you were then at Mantua:--

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Nay, I do bear a brain:--but, as I said,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Of my dug and felt it bitter, pretty fool,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: To see it tetchy and fall out with the dug!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Shake quoth the dove-house: 'twas no need, I trow,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: To bid me trudge:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: And since that time it is eleven years;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: For then she could stand alone; nay, by the rood,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: She could have run and waddled all about;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: For even the day before, she broke her brow:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: And then my husband--God be with his soul!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: A' was a merry man--took up the child:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: 'Yea,' quoth he, 'dost thou fall upon thy face?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Thou wilt fall backward when thou hast more wit;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Wilt thou not, Jule?' and, by my holidame,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: The pretty wretch left crying and said 'Ay.'

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: To see, now, how a jest shall come about!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I warrant, an I should live a thousand years,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I never should forget it: 'Wilt thou not, Jule?' quoth he;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: And, pretty fool, it stinted and said 'Ay.'

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Enough of this; I pray thee, hold thy peace.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Yes, madam: yet I cannot choose but laugh,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: To think it should leave crying and say 'Ay.'

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: And yet, I warrant, it had upon its brow

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: A bump as big as a young cockerel's stone;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: A parlous knock; and it cried bitterly:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: 'Yea,' quoth my husband,'fall'st upon thy face?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Thou wilt fall backward when thou comest to age;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Wilt thou not, Jule?' it stinted and said 'Ay.'

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And stint thou too, I pray thee, nurse, say I.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Peace, I have done. God mark thee to his grace!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Thou wast the prettiest babe that e'er I nursed:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: An I might live to see thee married once,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I have my wish.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Marry, that 'marry' is the very theme

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: I came to talk of. Tell me, daughter Juliet,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: How stands your disposition to be married?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: It is an honour that I dream not of.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: An honour! were not I thine only nurse,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I would say thou hadst suck'd wisdom from thy teat.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Well, think of marriage now; younger than you,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Here in Verona, ladies of esteem,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Are made already mothers: by my count,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: I was your mother much upon these years

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: That you are now a maid. Thus then in brief:

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: The valiant Paris seeks you for his love.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: A man, young lady! lady, such a man

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: As all the world--why, he's a man of wax.

text_entry: Verona's summer hath not such a flower.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Nay, he's a flower; in faith, a very flower.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: What say you? can you love the gentleman?

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: This night you shall behold him at our feast;

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Read o'er the volume of young Paris' face,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: And find delight writ there with beauty's pen;

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Examine every married lineament,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: And see how one another lends content

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: And what obscured in this fair volume lies

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Find written in the margent of his eyes.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: This precious book of love, this unbound lover,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: To beautify him, only lacks a cover:

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: The fish lives in the sea, and 'tis much pride

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: For fair without the fair within to hide:

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: That book in many's eyes doth share the glory,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: That in gold clasps locks in the golden story;

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: So shall you share all that he doth possess,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: By having him, making yourself no less.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: No less! nay, bigger; women grow by men.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Speak briefly, can you like of Paris' love?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I'll look to like, if looking liking move:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: But no more deep will I endart mine eye

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Than your consent gives strength to make it fly.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Madam, the guests are come, supper served up, you

speaker: Servant
text_entry: called, my young lady asked for, the nurse cursed in

speaker: Servant
text_entry: the pantry, and every thing in extremity. I must

speaker: Servant
text_entry: hence to wait; I beseech you, follow straight.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: We follow thee.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Exit Servant

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Juliet, the county stays.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Go, girl, seek happy nights to happy days.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: SCENE IV. A street.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Enter ROMEO, MERCUTIO, BENVOLIO, with five or six Maskers, Torch-bearers, and others

text_entry: What, shall this speech be spoke for our excuse?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Or shall we on without a apology?

text_entry: The date is out of such prolixity:

text_entry: Bearing a Tartar's painted bow of lath,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Scaring the ladies like a crow-keeper;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Nor no without-book prologue, faintly spoke

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: After the prompter, for our entrance:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: But let them measure us by what they will;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: We'll measure them a measure, and be gone.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Give me a torch: I am not for this ambling;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Being but heavy, I will bear the light.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Not I, believe me: you have dancing shoes

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: With nimble soles: I have a soul of lead

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: So stakes me to the ground I cannot move.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: You are a lover; borrow Cupid's wings,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And soar with them above a common bound.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I am too sore enpierced with his shaft

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: To soar with his light feathers, and so bound,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Under love's heavy burden do I sink.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And, to sink in it, should you burden love;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Too great oppression for a tender thing.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Is love a tender thing? it is too rough,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Too rude, too boisterous, and it pricks like thorn.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: If love be rough with you, be rough with love;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Prick love for pricking, and you beat love down.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Give me a case to put my visage in:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: A visor for a visor! what care I

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: What curious eye doth quote deformities?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Here are the beetle brows shall blush for me.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Come, knock and enter; and no sooner in,

text_entry: But every man betake him to his legs.

text_entry: A torch for me: let wantons light of heart

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: For I am proverb'd with a grandsire phrase;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I'll be a candle-holder, and look on.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: The game was ne'er so fair, and I am done.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Tut, dun's the mouse, the constable's own word:

text_entry: If thou art dun, we'll draw thee from the mire

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Of this sir-reverence love, wherein thou stick'st

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Up to the ears. Come, we burn daylight, ho!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Nay, that's not so.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: I mean, sir, in delay

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: We waste our lights in vain, like lamps by day.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Take our good meaning, for our judgment sits

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Five times in that ere once in our five wits.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And we mean well in going to this mask;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: But 'tis no wit to go.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Why, may one ask?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I dream'd a dream to-night.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And so did I.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Well, what was yours?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: That dreamers often lie.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: In bed asleep, while they do dream things true.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: O, then, I see Queen Mab hath been with you.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: She is the fairies' midwife, and she comes

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: In shape no bigger than an agate-stone

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: On the fore-finger of an alderman,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Drawn with a team of little atomies

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Athwart men's noses as they lie asleep;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Her wagon-spokes made of long spiders' legs,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: The cover of the wings of grasshoppers,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: The traces of the smallest spider's web,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: The collars of the moonshine's watery beams,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Her whip of cricket's bone, the lash of film,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Her wagoner a small grey-coated gnat,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Not so big as a round little worm

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Prick'd from the lazy finger of a maid;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Her chariot is an empty hazel-nut

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Made by the joiner squirrel or old grub,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Time out o' mind the fairies' coachmakers.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And in this state she gallops night by night

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Through lovers' brains, and then they dream of love;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: O'er courtiers' knees, that dream on court'sies straight,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: O'er lawyers' fingers, who straight dream on fees,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: O'er ladies ' lips, who straight on kisses dream,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Because their breaths with sweetmeats tainted are:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Sometime she gallops o'er a courtier's nose,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And then dreams he of smelling out a suit;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig's tail

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Tickling a parson's nose as a' lies asleep,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Then dreams, he of another benefice:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Sometime she driveth o'er a soldier's neck,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And then dreams he of cutting foreign throats,

speaker: MERCUTIO

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Of healths five-fathom deep; and then anon

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Drums in his ear, at which he starts and wakes,

speaker: MERCUTIO

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And sleeps again. This is that very Mab

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: That plats the manes of horses in the night,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And bakes the elflocks in foul sluttish hairs,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Which once untangled, much misfortune bodes:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: This is the hag, when maids lie on their backs,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: That presses them and learns them first to bear,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Making them women of good carriage:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: This is she--

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Thou talk'st of nothing.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: True, I talk of dreams,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Which are the children of an idle brain,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Begot of nothing but vain fantasy,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Which is as thin of substance as the air

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And more inconstant than the wind, who wooes

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Even now the frozen bosom of the north,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And, being anger'd, puffs away from thence,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Turning his face to the dew-dropping south.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: This wind, you talk of, blows us from ourselves;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Supper is done, and we shall come too late.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I fear, too early: for my mind misgives

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Some consequence yet hanging in the stars

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Shall bitterly begin his fearful date

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: With this night's revels and expire the term

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Of a despised life closed in my breast

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: By some vile forfeit of untimely death.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: But He, that hath the steerage of my course,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Direct my sail! On, lusty gentlemen.

speaker: BENVOLIO
