text_entry: Were in a mask?

speaker: Second Capulet
text_entry: By'r lady, thirty years.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: What, man! 'tis not so much, 'tis not so much:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: 'Tis since the nuptials of Lucentio,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Come pentecost as quickly as it will,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Some five and twenty years; and then we mask'd.

speaker: Second Capulet
text_entry: 'Tis more, 'tis more, his son is elder, sir;

speaker: Second Capulet
text_entry: His son is thirty.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Will you tell me that?

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: His son was but a ward two years ago.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: [To a Servingman]  What lady is that, which doth

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: enrich the hand

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Of yonder knight?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: I know not, sir.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O, she doth teach the torches to burn bright!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Like a rich jewel in an Ethiope's ear;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Beauty too rich for use, for earth too dear!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: As yonder lady o'er her fellows shows.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: The measure done, I'll watch her place of stand,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And, touching hers, make blessed my rude hand.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Did my heart love till now? forswear it, sight!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: This, by his voice, should be a Montague.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Fetch me my rapier, boy. What dares the slave

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Come hither, cover'd with an antic face,

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: To fleer and scorn at our solemnity?

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Now, by the stock and honour of my kin,

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: To strike him dead, I hold it not a sin.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Why, how now, kinsman! wherefore storm you so?

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe,

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: A villain that is hither come in spite,

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: To scorn at our solemnity this night.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Young Romeo is it?

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: 'Tis he, that villain Romeo.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Content thee, gentle coz, let him alone;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: He bears him like a portly gentleman;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And, to say truth, Verona brags of him

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: To be a virtuous and well-govern'd youth:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: I would not for the wealth of all the town

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Here in my house do him disparagement:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Therefore be patient, take no note of him:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: It is my will, the which if thou respect,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Show a fair presence and put off these frowns,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And ill-beseeming semblance for a feast.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: It fits, when such a villain is a guest:

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: I'll not endure him.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: He shall be endured:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: What, goodman boy! I say, he shall: go to;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Am I the master here, or you? go to.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: You'll not endure him! God shall mend my soul!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: You'll make a mutiny among my guests!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: You will set cock-a-hoop! you'll be the man!

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Why, uncle, 'tis a shame.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Go to, go to;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: You are a saucy boy: is't so, indeed?

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: This trick may chance to scathe you, I know what:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: You must contrary me! marry, 'tis time.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Well said, my hearts! You are a princox; go:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Be quiet, or--More light, more light! For shame!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: I'll make you quiet. What, cheerly, my hearts!

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Patience perforce with wilful choler meeting

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: I will withdraw: but this intrusion shall

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Now seeming sweet convert to bitter gall.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: [To JULIET]  If I profane with my unworthiest hand

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: This holy shrine, the gentle fine is this:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: To smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Which mannerly devotion shows in this;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: For saints have hands that pilgrims' hands do touch,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And palm to palm is holy palmers' kiss.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: They pray, grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Saints do not move, though grant for prayers' sake.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Then move not, while my prayer's effect I take.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Thus from my lips, by yours, my sin is purged.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Then have my lips the sin that they have took.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Sin from thy lips? O trespass sweetly urged!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Give me my sin again.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: You kiss by the book.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Madam, your mother craves a word with you.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What is her mother?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Marry, bachelor,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Her mother is the lady of the house,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: And a good lady, and a wise and virtuous

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I nursed her daughter, that you talk'd withal;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I tell you, he that can lay hold of her

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Shall have the chinks.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Is she a Capulet?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O dear account! my life is my foe's debt.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Away, begone; the sport is at the best.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Ay, so I fear; the more is my unrest.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Is it e'en so? why, then, I thank you all

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: I thank you, honest gentlemen; good night.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: More torches here! Come on then, let's to bed.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Ah, sirrah, by my fay, it waxes late:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: I'll to my rest.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Exeunt all but JULIET and Nurse

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Come hither, nurse. What is yond gentleman?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: The son and heir of old Tiberio.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What's he that now is going out of door?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Marry, that, I think, be young Petrucio.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What's he that follows there, that would not dance?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I know not.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Go ask his name: if he be married.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: My grave is like to be my wedding bed.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: His name is Romeo, and a Montague;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: The only son of your great enemy.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: My only love sprung from my only hate!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Too early seen unknown, and known too late!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Prodigious birth of love it is to me,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That I must love a loathed enemy.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: What's this? what's this?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: A rhyme I learn'd even now

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Of one I danced withal.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: One calls within 'Juliet.'

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Anon, anon!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Come, let's away; the strangers all are gone.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: PROLOGUE

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Enter Chorus

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Now old desire doth in his death-bed lie,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And young affection gapes to be his heir;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: That fair for which love groan'd for and would die,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: With tender Juliet match'd, is now not fair.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Now Romeo is beloved and loves again,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Alike betwitched by the charm of looks,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: But to his foe supposed he must complain,

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And she steal love's sweet bait from fearful hooks:

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Being held a foe, he may not have access

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear;

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: And she as much in love, her means much less

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: To meet her new-beloved any where:

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: But passion lends them power, time means, to meet

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Tempering extremities with extreme sweet.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: SCENE I. A lane by the wall of Capulet's orchard.

speaker: Chorus
text_entry: Enter ROMEO

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Can I go forward when my heart is here?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Turn back, dull earth, and find thy centre out.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: He climbs the wall, and leaps down within it

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Enter BENVOLIO and MERCUTIO

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Romeo! my cousin Romeo!

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: He is wise;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And, on my lie, hath stol'n him home to bed.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: He ran this way, and leap'd this orchard wall:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Call, good Mercutio.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Nay, I'll conjure too.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Romeo! humours! madman! passion! lover!

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Cry but 'Ay me!' pronounce but 'love' and 'dove;'

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: One nick-name for her purblind son and heir,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Young Adam Cupid, he that shot so trim,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: When King Cophetua loved the beggar-maid!

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: The ape is dead, and I must conjure him.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: I conjure thee by Rosaline's bright eyes,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: By her high forehead and her scarlet lip,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: By her fine foot, straight leg and quivering thigh

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And the demesnes that there adjacent lie,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: That in thy likeness thou appear to us!

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And if he hear thee, thou wilt anger him.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: This cannot anger him: 'twould anger him

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: To raise a spirit in his mistress' circle

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Of some strange nature, letting it there stand

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Till she had laid it and conjured it down;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: That were some spite: my invocation

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Is fair and honest, and in his mistres s' name

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: I conjure only but to raise up him.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Come, he hath hid himself among these trees,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: To be consorted with the humorous night:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Blind is his love and best befits the dark.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Now will he sit under a medlar tree,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: As maids call medlars, when they laugh alone.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Romeo, that she were, O, that she were

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: An open et caetera, thou a poperin pear!

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Romeo, good night: I'll to my truckle-bed;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: This field-bed is too cold for me to sleep:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Come, shall we go?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Go, then; for 'tis in vain

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: To seek him here that means not to be found.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: SCENE II. Capulet's orchard.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Enter ROMEO

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: He jests at scars that never felt a wound.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: JULIET appears above at a window

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: But, soft! what light through yonder window breaks?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: It is the east, and Juliet is the sun.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Arise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Who is already sick and pale with grief,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: That thou her maid art far more fair than she:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Be not her maid, since she is envious;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Her vestal livery is but sick and green

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And none but fools do wear it; cast it off.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: It is my lady, O, it is my love!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O, that she knew she were!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: She speaks yet she says nothing: what of that?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Her eye discourses; I will answer it.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I am too bold, 'tis not to me she speaks:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Having some business, do entreat her eyes

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: To twinkle in their spheres till they return.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What if her eyes were there, they in her head?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: As daylight doth a lamp; her eyes in heaven

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Would through the airy region stream so bright

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: That birds would sing and think it were not night.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: See, how she leans her cheek upon her hand!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O, that I were a glove upon that hand,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: That I might touch that cheek!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Ay me!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: She speaks:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O, speak again, bright angel! for thou art

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: As glorious to this night, being o'er my head

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: As is a winged messenger of heaven

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Unto the white-upturned wondering eyes

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: When he bestrides the lazy-pacing clouds

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And sails upon the bosom of the air.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O Romeo, Romeo! wherefore art thou Romeo?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Deny thy father and refuse thy name;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And I'll no longer be a Capulet.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: [Aside]  Shall I hear more, or shall I speak at this?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: 'Tis but thy name that is my enemy;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Thou art thyself, though not a Montague.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What's Montague? it is nor hand, nor foot,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Nor arm, nor face, nor any other part

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Belonging to a man. O, be some other name!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What's in a name? that which we call a rose

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: By any other name would smell as sweet;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: So Romeo would, were he not Romeo call'd,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Retain that dear perfection which he owes

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Without that title. Romeo, doff thy name,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And for that name which is no part of thee

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Take all myself.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I take thee at thy word:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Call me but love, and I'll be new baptized;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Henceforth I never will be Romeo.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What man art thou that thus bescreen'd in night

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: So stumblest on my counsel?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: By a name

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I know not how to tell thee who I am:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Because it is an enemy to thee;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Had I it written, I would tear the word.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Of that tongue's utterance, yet I know the sound:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Art thou not Romeo and a Montague?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Neither, fair saint, if either thee dislike.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: How camest thou hither, tell me, and wherefore?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: The orchard walls are high and hard to climb,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And the place death, considering who thou art,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: If any of my kinsmen find thee here.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: With love's light wings did I o'er-perch these walls;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: For stony limits cannot hold love out,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And what love can do that dares love attempt;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Therefore thy kinsmen are no let to me.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: If they do see thee, they will murder thee.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Alack, there lies more peril in thine eye

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Than twenty of their swords: look thou but sweet,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And I am proof against their enmity.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I would not for the world they saw thee here.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I have night's cloak to hide me from their sight;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And but thou love me, let them find me here:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: My life were better ended by their hate,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Than death prorogued, wanting of thy love.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: By whose direction found'st thou out this place?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: By love, who first did prompt me to inquire;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: He lent me counsel and I lent him eyes.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I am no pilot; yet, wert thou as far

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: As that vast shore wash'd with the farthest sea,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I would adventure for such merchandise.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Thou know'st the mask of night is on my face,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: For that which thou hast heard me speak to-night

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Fain would I dwell on form, fain, fain deny

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What I have spoke: but farewell compliment!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Dost thou love me? I know thou wilt say 'Ay,'

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And I will take thy word: yet if thou swear'st,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Thou mayst prove false; at lovers' perjuries

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Then say, Jove laughs. O gentle Romeo,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or if thou think'st I am too quickly won,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I'll frown and be perverse an say thee nay,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: So thou wilt woo; but else, not for the world.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: In truth, fair Montague, I am too fond,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And therefore thou mayst think my 'havior light:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: But trust me, gentleman, I'll prove more true

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Than those that have more cunning to be strange.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I should have been more strange, I must confess,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: But that thou overheard'st, ere I was ware,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: My true love's passion: therefore pardon me,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And not impute this yielding to light love,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Which the dark night hath so discovered.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Lady, by yonder blessed moon I swear

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops--

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O, swear not by the moon, the inconstant moon,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That monthly changes in her circled orb,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What shall I swear by?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Do not swear at all;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Which is the god of my idolatry,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And I'll believe thee.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: If my heart's dear love--

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Well, do not swear: although I joy in thee,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I have no joy of this contract to-night:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: It is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Ere one can say 'It lightens.' Sweet, good night!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: This bud of love, by summer's ripening breath,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Good night, good night! as sweet repose and rest

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Come to thy heart as that within my breast!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O, wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What satisfaction canst thou have to-night?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: The exchange of thy love's faithful vow for mine.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I gave thee mine before thou didst request it:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And yet I would it were to give again.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Wouldst thou withdraw it? for what purpose, love?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: But to be frank, and give it thee again.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And yet I wish but for the thing I have:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: My bounty is as boundless as the sea,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: My love as deep; the more I give to thee,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: The more I have, for both are infinite.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Nurse calls within

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I hear some noise within; dear love, adieu!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Anon, good nurse! Sweet Montague, be true.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Stay but a little, I will come again.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Exit, above

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O blessed, blessed night! I am afeard.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Being in night, all this is but a dream,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Too flattering-sweet to be substantial.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Re-enter JULIET, above

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: If that thy bent of love be honourable,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Thy purpose marriage, send me word to-morrow,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: By one that I'll procure to come to thee,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And all my fortunes at thy foot I'll lay

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And follow thee my lord throughout the world.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: [Within]  Madam!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I come, anon.--But if thou mean'st not well,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I do beseech thee--

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: [Within]  Madam!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: By and by, I come:--

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To cease thy suit, and leave me to my grief:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To-morrow will I send.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: So thrive my soul--

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: A thousand times good night!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Exit, above

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: A thousand times the worse, to want thy light.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Love goes toward love, as schoolboys from

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: their books,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: But love from love, toward school with heavy looks.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Retiring

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Re-enter JULIET, above

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Hist! Romeo, hist! O, for a falconer's voice,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To lure this tassel-gentle back again!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: With repetition of my Romeo's name.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: It is my soul that calls upon my name:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Like softest music to attending ears!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Romeo!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: My dear?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: At what o'clock to-morrow

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Shall I send to thee?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: At the hour of nine.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I will not fail: 'tis twenty years till then.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I have forgot why I did call thee back.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Let me stand here till thou remember it.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I shall forget, to have thee still stand there,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Remembering how I love thy company.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And I'll still stay, to have thee still forget,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Forgetting any other home but this.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: 'Tis almost morning; I would have thee gone:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And yet no further than a wanton's bird;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Who lets it hop a little from her hand,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And with a silk thread plucks it back again,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: So loving-jealous of his liberty.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I would I were thy bird.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Sweet, so would I:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Good night, good night! parting is such

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: sweet sorrow,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That I shall say good night till it be morrow.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Exit above

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Would I were sleep and peace, so sweet to rest!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Hence will I to my ghostly father's cell,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: His help to crave, and my dear hap to tell.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: SCENE III. Friar Laurence's cell.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Enter FRIAR LAURENCE, with a basket

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: The grey-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Chequering the eastern clouds with streaks of light,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And flecked darkness like a drunkard reels

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: From forth day's path and Titan's fiery wheels:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: The day to cheer and night's dank dew to dry,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: I must up-fill this osier cage of ours

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: With baleful weeds and precious-juiced flowers.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: The earth that's nature's mother is her tomb;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: What is her burying grave that is her womb,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And from her womb children of divers kind

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: We sucking on her natural bosom find,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Many for many virtues excellent,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: None but for some and yet all different.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: O, mickle is the powerful grace that lies

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: In herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: For nought so vile that on the earth doth live

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: But to the earth some special good doth give,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Nor aught so good but strain'd from that fair use

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And vice sometimes by action dignified.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Within the infant rind of this small flower

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Poison hath residence and medicine power:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: For this, being smelt, with that part cheers each part;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Being tasted, slays all senses with the heart.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Two such opposed kings encamp them still

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: In man as well as herbs, grace and rude will;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And where the worser is predominant,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Enter ROMEO

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Good morrow, father.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Benedicite!

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Young son, it argues a distemper'd head

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Care keeps his watch in every old man's eye,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And where care lodges, sleep will never lie;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: But where unbruised youth with unstuff'd brain

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep doth reign:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Therefore thy earliness doth me assure

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thou art up-roused by some distemperature;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Or if not so, then here I hit it right,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Our Romeo hath not been in bed to-night.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: That last is true; the sweeter rest was mine.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: God pardon sin! wast thou with Rosaline?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: With Rosaline, my ghostly father? no;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I have forgot that name, and that name's woe.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: That's my good son: but where hast thou been, then?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I'll tell thee, ere thou ask it me again.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I have been feasting with mine enemy,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Where on a sudden one hath wounded me,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: That's by me wounded: both our remedies

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Within thy help and holy physic lies:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I bear no hatred, blessed man, for, lo,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: My intercession likewise steads my foe.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Be plain, good son, and homely in thy drift;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Then plainly know my heart's dear love is set

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: On the fair daughter of rich Capulet:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: As mine on hers, so hers is set on mine;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And all combined, save what thou must combine

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: By holy marriage: when and where and how

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: We met, we woo'd and made exchange of vow,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I'll tell thee as we pass; but this I pray,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: That thou consent to marry us to-day.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Holy Saint Francis, what a change is here!

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Is Rosaline, whom thou didst love so dear,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: So soon forsaken? young men's love then lies

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Jesu Maria, what a deal of brine

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Hath wash'd thy sallow cheeks for Rosaline!

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: How much salt water thrown away in waste,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To season love, that of it doth not taste!

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thy old groans ring yet in my ancient ears;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Lo, here upon thy cheek the stain doth sit

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Of an old tear that is not wash'd off yet:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: If e'er thou wast thyself and these woes thine,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And art thou changed? pronounce this sentence then,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Women may fall, when there's no strength in men.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Thou chid'st me oft for loving Rosaline.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: For doting, not for loving, pupil mine.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And bad'st me bury love.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Not in a grave,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To lay one in, another out to have.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I pray thee, chide not; she whom I love now

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Doth grace for grace and love for love allow;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: The other did not so.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: O, she knew well

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thy love did read by rote and could not spell.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: But come, young waverer, come, go with me,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: In one respect I'll thy assistant be;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: For this alliance may so happy prove,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To turn your households' rancour to pure love.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O, let us hence; I stand on sudden haste.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Wisely and slow; they stumble that run fast.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: SCENE IV. A street.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Enter BENVOLIO and MERCUTIO

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Where the devil should this Romeo be?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Came he not home to-night?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Not to his father's; I spoke with his man.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Ah, that same pale hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Torments him so, that he will sure run mad.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Tybalt, the kinsman of old Capulet,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Hath sent a letter to his father's house.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: A challenge, on my life.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Romeo will answer it.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Any man that can write may answer a letter.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Nay, he will answer the letter's master, how he

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: dares, being dared.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Alas poor Romeo! he is already dead; stabbed with a

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: white wench's black eye; shot through the ear with a

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: love-song; the very pin of his heart cleft with the

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: blind bow-boy's butt-shaft: and is he a man to

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: encounter Tybalt?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Why, what is Tybalt?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: More than prince of cats, I can tell you. O, he is

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: the courageous captain of compliments. He fights as

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: you sing prick-song, keeps time, distance, and

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: proportion; rests me his minim rest, one, two, and

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: the third in your bosom: the very butcher of a silk

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: button, a duellist, a duellist; a gentleman of the

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: very first house, of the first and second cause:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: ah, the immortal passado! the punto reverso! the

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: hai!

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: The what?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: The pox of such antic, lisping, affecting

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: fantasticoes; these new tuners of accents! 'By Jesu,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: a very good blade! a very tall man! a very good

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: whore!' Why, is not this a lamentable thing,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: grandsire, that we should be thus afflicted with

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: these strange flies, these fashion-mongers, these

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: perdona-mi's, who stand so much on the new form,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: that they cannot at ease on the old bench? O, their

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: bones, their bones!

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Enter ROMEO

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Without his roe, like a dried herring: flesh, flesh,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: how art thou fishified! Now is he for the numbers

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: that Petrarch flowed in: Laura to his lady was but a

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: kitchen-wench; marry, she had a better love to

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: be-rhyme her; Dido a dowdy; Cleopatra a gipsy;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Helen and Hero hildings and harlots; Thisbe a grey

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: eye or so, but not to the purpose. Signior

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Romeo, bon jour! there's a French salutation

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: to your French slop. You gave us the counterfeit

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: fairly last night.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Good morrow to you both. What counterfeit did I give you?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: The ship, sir, the slip; can you not conceive?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Pardon, good Mercutio, my business was great; and in

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: such a case as mine a man may strain courtesy.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: That's as much as to say, such a case as yours

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: constrains a man to bow in the hams.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Meaning, to court'sy.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Thou hast most kindly hit it.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: A most courteous exposition.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Nay, I am the very pink of courtesy.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Pink for flower.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Right.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Why, then is my pump well flowered.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Well said: follow me this jest now till thou hast

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: worn out thy pump, that when the single sole of it

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: is worn, the jest may remain after the wearing sole singular.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O single-soled jest, solely singular for the

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: singleness.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Come between us, good Benvolio; my wits faint.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Switch and spurs, switch and spurs; or I'll cry a match.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Nay, if thy wits run the wild-goose chase, I have

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: done, for thou hast more of the wild-goose in one of

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: thy wits than, I am sure, I have in my whole five:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: was I with you there for the goose?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Thou wast never with me for any thing when thou wast

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: not there for the goose.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: I will bite thee by the ear for that jest.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Nay, good goose, bite not.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting; it is a most

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: sharp sauce.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And is it not well served in to a sweet goose?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: O here's a wit of cheveril, that stretches from an

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: inch narrow to an ell broad!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I stretch it out for that word 'broad;' which added

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: to the goose, proves thee far and wide a broad goose.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Why, is not this better now than groaning for love?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: now art thou sociable, now art thou Romeo; now art

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: thou what thou art, by art as well as by nature:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: for this drivelling love is like a great natural,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: that runs lolling up and down to hide his bauble in a hole.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Stop there, stop there.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Thou desirest me to stop in my tale against the hair.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Thou wouldst else have made thy tale large.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: O, thou art deceived; I would have made it short:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: for I was come to the whole depth of my tale; and

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: meant, indeed, to occupy the argument no longer.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Here's goodly gear!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Enter Nurse and PETER

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: A sail, a sail!

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Two, two; a shirt and a smock.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Peter!

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Anon!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: My fan, Peter.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Good Peter, to hide her face; for her fan's the

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: fairer face.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: God ye good morrow, gentlemen.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: God ye good den, fair gentlewoman.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Is it good den?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: 'Tis no less, I tell you, for the bawdy hand of the

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: dial is now upon the prick of noon.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Out upon you! what a man are you!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: One, gentlewoman, that God hath made for himself to

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: mar.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: By my troth, it is well said; 'for himself to mar,'

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: quoth a'? Gentlemen, can any of you tell me where I

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: may find the young Romeo?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I can tell you; but young Romeo will be older when

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: you have found him than he was when you sought him:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I am the youngest of that name, for fault of a worse.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: You say well.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Yea, is the worst well? very well took, i' faith;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: wisely, wisely.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: if you be he, sir, I desire some confidence with

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: you.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: She will indite him to some supper.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: A bawd, a bawd, a bawd! so ho!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What hast thou found?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: No hare, sir; unless a hare, sir, in a lenten pie,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: that is something stale and hoar ere it be spent.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Sings

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: An old hare hoar,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And an old hare hoar,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Is very good meat in lent

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: But a hare that is hoar

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Is too much for a score,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: When it hoars ere it be spent.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Romeo, will you come to your father's? we'll

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: to dinner, thither.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I will follow you.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Farewell, ancient lady; farewell,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Singing

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: 'lady, lady, lady.'

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Exeunt MERCUTIO and BENVOLIO

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Marry, farewell! I pray you, sir, what saucy

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: merchant was this, that was so full of his ropery?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: A gentleman, nurse, that loves to hear himself talk,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: and will speak more in a minute than he will stand

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: to in a month.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: An a' speak any thing against me, I'll take him

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: down, an a' were lustier than he is, and twenty such

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Jacks; and if I cannot, I'll find those that shall.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Scurvy knave! I am none of his flirt-gills; I am

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: none of his skains-mates. And thou must stand by

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: too, and suffer every knave to use me at his pleasure?

speaker: PETER
text_entry: I saw no man use you a pleasure; if I had, my weapon

speaker: PETER
text_entry: should quickly have been out, I warrant you: I dare

speaker: PETER
text_entry: draw as soon as another man, if I see occasion in a

speaker: PETER
text_entry: good quarrel, and the law on my side.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Now, afore God, I am so vexed, that every part about

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: me quivers. Scurvy knave! Pray you, sir, a word:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: and as I told you, my young lady bade me inquire you

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: out; what she bade me say, I will keep to myself:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: but first let me tell ye, if ye should lead her into

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: a fool's paradise, as they say, it were a very gross

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: kind of behavior, as they say: for the gentlewoman

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: is young; and, therefore, if you should deal double

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: with her, truly it were an ill thing to be offered

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: to any gentlewoman, and very weak dealing.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Nurse, commend me to thy lady and mistress. I

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: protest unto thee--

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Good heart, and, i' faith, I will tell her as much:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Lord, Lord, she will be a joyful woman.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What wilt thou tell her, nurse? thou dost not mark me.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I will tell her, sir, that you do protest; which, as

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I take it, is a gentlemanlike offer.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Bid her devise

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Some means to come to shrift this afternoon;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And there she shall at Friar Laurence' cell

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Be shrived and married. Here is for thy pains.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: No truly sir; not a penny.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Go to; I say you shall.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: This afternoon, sir? well, she shall be there.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And stay, good nurse, behind the abbey wall:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Within this hour my man shall be with thee

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And bring thee cords made like a tackled stair;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Which to the high top-gallant of my joy

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Must be my convoy in the secret night.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Farewell; be trusty, and I'll quit thy pains:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Farewell; commend me to thy mistress.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Now God in heaven bless thee! Hark you, sir.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What say'st thou, my dear nurse?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Is your man secret? Did you ne'er hear say,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Two may keep counsel, putting one away?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I warrant thee, my man's as true as steel.

speaker: NURSE
text_entry: Well, sir; my mistress is the sweetest lady--Lord,

speaker: NURSE
text_entry: Lord! when 'twas a little prating thing:--O, there

speaker: NURSE
text_entry: is a nobleman in town, one Paris, that would fain

speaker: NURSE
text_entry: lay knife aboard; but she, good soul, had as lief

speaker: NURSE
text_entry: see a toad, a very toad, as see him. I anger her

speaker: NURSE
text_entry: sometimes and tell her that Paris is the properer

speaker: NURSE
text_entry: man; but, I'll warrant you, when I say so, she looks

speaker: NURSE
text_entry: as pale as any clout in the versal world. Doth not

speaker: NURSE
text_entry: rosemary and Romeo begin both with a letter?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Ay, nurse; what of that? both with an R.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Ah. mocker! that's the dog's name; R is for

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: the--No; I know it begins with some other

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: letter:--and she hath the prettiest sententious of

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: it, of you and rosemary, that it would do you good

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: to hear it.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Commend me to thy lady.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Ay, a thousand times.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Exit Romeo

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Peter!

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Anon!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Peter, take my fan, and go before and apace.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: SCENE V. Capulet's orchard.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Enter JULIET

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: The clock struck nine when I did send the nurse;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: In half an hour she promised to return.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Perchance she cannot meet him: that's not so.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O, she is lame! love's heralds should be thoughts,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Which ten times faster glide than the sun's beams,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Driving back shadows over louring hills:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Therefore do nimble-pinion'd doves draw love,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And therefore hath the wind-swift Cupid wings.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Now is the sun upon the highmost hill

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Of this day's journey, and from nine till twelve

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Is three long hours, yet she is not come.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Had she affections and warm youthful blood,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: She would be as swift in motion as a ball;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: My words would bandy her to my sweet love,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And his to me:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: But old folks, many feign as they were dead;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Unwieldy, slow, heavy and pale as lead.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O God, she comes!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Enter Nurse and PETER

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O honey nurse, what news?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Hast thou met with him? Send thy man away.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Peter, stay at the gate.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Exit PETER

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Now, good sweet nurse,--O Lord, why look'st thou sad?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Though news be sad, yet tell them merrily;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: If good, thou shamest the music of sweet news

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: By playing it to me with so sour a face.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I am a-weary, give me leave awhile:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Fie, how my bones ache! what a jaunt have I had!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I would thou hadst my bones, and I thy news:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Nay, come, I pray thee, speak; good, good nurse, speak.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Jesu, what haste? can you not stay awhile?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Do you not see that I am out of breath?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: How art thou out of breath, when thou hast breath

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To say to me that thou art out of breath?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: The excuse that thou dost make in this delay

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Is longer than the tale thou dost excuse.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Is thy news good, or bad? answer to that;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Say either, and I'll stay the circumstance:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Let me be satisfied, is't good or bad?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Well, you have made a simple choice; you know not

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: how to choose a man: Romeo! no, not he; though his

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: face be better than any man's, yet his leg excels

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: all men's; and for a hand, and a foot, and a body,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: though they be not to be talked on, yet they are

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: past compare: he is not the flower of courtesy,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: but, I'll warrant him, as gentle as a lamb. Go thy

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: ways, wench; serve God. What, have you dined at home?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: No, no: but all this did I know before.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What says he of our marriage? what of that?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Lord, how my head aches! what a head have I!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: It beats as it would fall in twenty pieces.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: My back o' t' other side,--O, my back, my back!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Beshrew your heart for sending me about,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: To catch my death with jaunting up and down!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I' faith, I am sorry that thou art not well.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Sweet, sweet, sweet nurse, tell me, what says my love?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, and a

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: courteous, and a kind, and a handsome, and, I

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: warrant, a virtuous,--Where is your mother?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Where is my mother! why, she is within;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Where should she be? How oddly thou repliest!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: 'Your love says, like an honest gentleman,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Where is your mother?'

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: O God's lady dear!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Are you so hot? marry, come up, I trow;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Is this the poultice for my aching bones?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Henceforward do your messages yourself.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Here's such a coil! come, what says Romeo?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Have you got leave to go to shrift to-day?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I have.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Then hie you hence to Friar Laurence' cell;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: There stays a husband to make you a wife:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Now comes the wanton blood up in your cheeks,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: They'll be in scarlet straight at any news.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Hie you to church; I must another way,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: To fetch a ladder, by the which your love

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Must climb a bird's nest soon when it is dark:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I am the drudge and toil in your delight,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: But you shall bear the burden soon at night.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Go; I'll to dinner: hie you to the cell.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Hie to high fortune! Honest nurse, farewell.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: SCENE VI. Friar Laurence's cell.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Enter FRIAR LAURENCE and ROMEO

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: So smile the heavens upon this holy act,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: That after hours with sorrow chide us not!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Amen, amen! but come what sorrow can,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: It cannot countervail the exchange of joy

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: That one short minute gives me in her sight:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Do thou but close our hands with holy words,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Then love-devouring death do what he dare;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: It is enough I may but call her mine.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: These violent delights have violent ends

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And in their triumph die, like fire and powder,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Which as they kiss consume: the sweetest honey

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Is loathsome in his own deliciousness

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And in the taste confounds the appetite:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Therefore love moderately; long love doth so;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Too swift arrives as tardy as too slow.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Enter JULIET

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Here comes the lady: O, so light a foot

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Will ne'er wear out the everlasting flint:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: A lover may bestride the gossamer

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: That idles in the wanton summer air,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And yet not fall; so light is vanity.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Good even to my ghostly confessor.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Romeo shall thank thee, daughter, for us both.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: As much to him, else is his thanks too much.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Ah, Juliet, if the measure of thy joy

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Be heap'd like mine and that thy skill be more

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: To blazon it, then sweeten with thy breath

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: This neighbour air, and let rich music's tongue

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Unfold the imagined happiness that both

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Receive in either by this dear encounter.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Conceit, more rich in matter than in words,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Brags of his substance, not of ornament:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: They are but beggars that can count their worth;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: But my true love is grown to such excess

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I cannot sum up sum of half my wealth.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Come, come with me, and we will make short work;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: For, by your leaves, you shall not stay alone

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Till holy church incorporate two in one.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: SCENE I. A public place.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Enter MERCUTIO, BENVOLIO, Page, and Servants

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: I pray thee, good Mercutio, let's retire:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: The day is hot, the Capulets abroad,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And, if we meet, we shall not scape a brawl;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: For now, these hot days, is the mad blood stirring.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Thou art like one of those fellows that when he

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: enters the confines of a tavern claps me his sword

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: upon the table and says 'God send me no need of

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: thee!' and by the operation of the second cup draws

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: it on the drawer, when indeed there is no need.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Am I like such a fellow?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Come, come, thou art as hot a Jack in thy mood as

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: any in Italy, and as soon moved to be moody, and as

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: soon moody to be moved.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And what to?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Nay, an there were two such, we should have none

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: shortly, for one would kill the other. Thou! why,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: thou wilt quarrel with a man that hath a hair more,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: or a hair less, in his beard, than thou hast: thou

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: wilt quarrel with a man for cracking nuts, having no

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: other reason but because thou hast hazel eyes: what

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: eye but such an eye would spy out such a quarrel?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Thy head is as fun of quarrels as an egg is full of

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: meat, and yet thy head hath been beaten as addle as

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: an egg for quarrelling: thou hast quarrelled with a

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: man for coughing in the street, because he hath

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep in the sun:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: didst thou not fall out with a tailor for wearing

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: his new doublet before Easter? with another, for

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: tying his new shoes with old riband? and yet thou

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: wilt tutor me from quarrelling!

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: An I were so apt to quarrel as thou art, any man

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: should buy the fee-simple of my life for an hour and a quarter.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: The fee-simple! O simple!

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: By my head, here come the Capulets.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: By my heel, I care not.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Enter TYBALT and others

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Follow me close, for I will speak to them.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Gentlemen, good den: a word with one of you.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And but one word with one of us? couple it with

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: something; make it a word and a blow.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, an you

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: will give me occasion.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Could you not take some occasion without giving?

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Mercutio, thou consort'st with Romeo,--

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Consort! what, dost thou make us minstrels? an

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: thou make minstrels of us, look to hear nothing but

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: discords: here's my fiddlestick; here's that shall

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: make you dance. 'Zounds, consort!

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: We talk here in the public haunt of men:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Either withdraw unto some private place,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And reason coldly of your grievances,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Or else depart; here all eyes gaze on us.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Men's eyes were made to look, and let them gaze;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: I will not budge for no man's pleasure, I.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Enter ROMEO

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Well, peace be with you, sir: here comes my man.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: But I'll be hanged, sir, if he wear your livery:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Marry, go before to field, he'll be your follower;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Your worship in that sense may call him 'man.'

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Romeo, the hate I bear thee can afford

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: No better term than this,--thou art a villain.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Tybalt, the reason that I have to love thee

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Doth much excuse the appertaining rage

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: To such a greeting: villain am I none;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Therefore farewell; I see thou know'st me not.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Boy, this shall not excuse the injuries

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: That thou hast done me; therefore turn and draw.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I do protest, I never injured thee,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: But love thee better than thou canst devise,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Till thou shalt know the reason of my love:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And so, good Capulet,--which name I tender

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: As dearly as my own,--be satisfied.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: O calm, dishonourable, vile submission!

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Alla stoccata carries it away.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Draws

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Tybalt, you rat-catcher, will you walk?

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: What wouldst thou have with me?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Good king of cats, nothing but one of your nine

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: lives; that I mean to make bold withal, and as you

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: shall use me hereafter, drybeat the rest of the

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: eight. Will you pluck your sword out of his pitcher

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: by the ears? make haste, lest mine be about your

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: ears ere it be out.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: I am for you.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Drawing

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Gentle Mercutio, put thy rapier up.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Come, sir, your passado.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: They fight

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Draw, Benvolio; beat down their weapons.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Gentlemen, for shame, forbear this outrage!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Tybalt, Mercutio, the prince expressly hath

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Forbidden bandying in Verona streets:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Hold, Tybalt! good Mercutio!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: TYBALT under ROMEO's arm stabs MERCUTIO, and flies with his followers

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: I am hurt.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: A plague o' both your houses! I am sped.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Is he gone, and hath nothing?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: What, art thou hurt?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Ay, ay, a scratch, a scratch; marry, 'tis enough.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Where is my page? Go, villain, fetch a surgeon.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Exit Page

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Courage, man; the hurt cannot be much.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: No, 'tis not so deep as a well, nor so wide as a

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: church-door; but 'tis enough,'twill serve: ask for

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: me to-morrow, and you shall find me a grave man. I

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: am peppered, I warrant, for this world. A plague o'

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: both your houses! 'Zounds, a dog, a rat, a mouse, a

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: cat, to scratch a man to death! a braggart, a

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: rogue, a villain, that fights by the book of

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: arithmetic! Why the devil came you between us? I

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: was hurt under your arm.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I thought all for the best.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Help me into some house, Benvolio,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Or I shall faint. A plague o' both your houses!

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: They have made worms' meat of me: I have it,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And soundly too: your houses!

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Exeunt MERCUTIO and BENVOLIO

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: This gentleman, the prince's near ally,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: My very friend, hath got his mortal hurt

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: In my behalf; my reputation stain'd

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: With Tybalt's slander,--Tybalt, that an hour

speaker: BENVOLIO

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Who all as hot, turns deadly point to point,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And, with a martial scorn, with one hand beats

text_entry: Cold death aside, and with the other sends

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: his tongue,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: But by and by comes back to Romeo,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Who had but newly entertain'd revenge,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And to 't they go like lightning, for, ere I

text_entry: Could draw to part them, was stout Tybalt slain.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And, as he fell, did Romeo turn and fly.

speaker: BENVOLIO

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: He is a kinsman to the Montague;

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Affection makes him false; he speaks not true:

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Some twenty of them fought in this black strife,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: And all those twenty could but kill one life.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: I beg for justice, which thou, prince, must give;

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Romeo slew Tybalt, Romeo must not live.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Romeo slew him, he slew Mercutio;

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Who now the price of his dear blood doth owe?

text_entry: Not Romeo, prince, he was Mercutio's friend;

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: His fault concludes but what the law should end,

speaker: MONTAGUE

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: And for that offence

speaker: PRINCE

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: But I'll amerce you with so strong a fine

speaker: PRINCE

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase out abuses:

speaker: PRINCE

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Else, when he's found, that hour is his last.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Bear hence this body and attend our will:

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Mercy but murders, pardoning those that kill.

speaker: PRINCE

speaker: PRINCE

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Enter JULIET

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Gallop apace, you fiery-footed steeds,

text_entry: Towards Phoebus' lodging: such a wagoner

text_entry: As Phaethon would whip you to the west,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And bring in cloudy night immediately.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Spread thy close curtain, love-performing night,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That runaway's eyes may wink and Romeo

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Leap to these arms, untalk'd of and unseen.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Lovers can see to do their amorous rites

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: By their own beauties; or, if love be blind,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: It best agrees with night. Come, civil night,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Thou sober-suited matron, all in black,

text_entry: And learn me how to lose a winning match,

speaker: JULIET

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Hood my unmann'd blood, bating in my cheeks,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: With thy black mantle; till strange love, grown bold,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Think true love acted simple modesty.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Come, night; come, Romeo; come, thou day in night;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: For thou wilt lie upon the wings of night

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Whiter than new snow on a raven's back.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Come, gentle night, come, loving, black-brow'd night,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Give me my Romeo; and, when he shall die,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Take him and cut him out in little stars,

speaker: JULIET

speaker: JULIET

speaker: JULIET

text_entry: O, I have bought the mansion of a love,

text_entry: But not possess'd it, and, though I am sold,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Not yet enjoy'd: so tedious is this day

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: As is the night before some festival

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To an impatient child that hath new robes

text_entry: And may not wear them. O, here comes my nurse,

text_entry: Ah, well-a-day! he's dead, he's dead, he's dead!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: We are undone, lady, we are undone!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Alack the day! he's gone, he's kill'd, he's dead!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Romeo can,

text_entry: Than the death-darting eye of cockatrice:

speaker: JULIET

text_entry: I saw the wound, I saw it with mine eyes,--

text_entry: God save the mark!--here on his manly breast:

text_entry: A piteous corse, a bloody piteous corse;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Pale, pale as ashes, all bedaub'd in blood,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: All in gore-blood; I swounded at the sight.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To prison, eyes, ne'er look on liberty!

text_entry: Vile earth, to earth resign; end motion here;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And thou and Romeo press one heavy bier!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: O Tybalt, Tybalt, the best friend I had!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: O courteous Tybalt! honest gentleman!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: That ever I should live to see thee dead!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What storm is this that blows so contrary?

speaker: JULIET

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: My dear-loved cousin, and my dearer lord?

text_entry: For who is living, if those two are gone?

text_entry: Tybalt is gone, and Romeo banished;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Romeo that kill'd him, he is banished.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: It did, it did; alas the day, it did!

text_entry: When thou didst bower the spirit of a fiend

text_entry: All forsworn, all naught, all dissemblers.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Ah, where's my man? give me some aqua vitae:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: These griefs, these woes, these sorrows make me old.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Shame come to Romeo!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Blister'd be thy tongue

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: For such a wish! he was not born to shame:

text_entry: Upon his brow shame is ashamed to sit;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: For 'tis a throne where honour may be crown'd

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Sole monarch of the universal earth.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O, what a beast was I to chide at him!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Will you speak well of him that kill'd your cousin?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Shall I speak ill of him that is my husband?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Ah, poor my lord, what tongue shall smooth thy name,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: When I, thy three-hours wife, have mangled it?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: But, wherefore, villain, didst thou kill my cousin?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That villain cousin would have kill'd my husband:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Back, foolish tears, back to your native spring;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Your tributary drops belong to woe,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Which you, mistaking, offer up to joy.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: My husband lives, that Tybalt would have slain;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And Tybalt's dead, that would have slain my husband:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: All this is comfort; wherefore weep I then?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Some word there was, worser than Tybalt's death,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That murder'd me: I would forget it fain;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: But, O, it presses to my memory,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Like damned guilty deeds to sinners' minds:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: 'Tybalt is dead, and Romeo--banished;'

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That 'banished,' that one word 'banished,'

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Hath slain ten thousand Tybalts. Tybalt's death

text_entry: Was woe enough, if it had ended there:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or, if sour woe delights in fellowship

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And needly will be rank'd with other griefs,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Why follow'd not, when she said 'Tybalt's dead,'

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Thy father, or thy mother, nay, or both,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Which modern lamentations might have moved?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: But with a rear-ward following Tybalt's death,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: 'Romeo is banished,' to speak that word,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Is father, mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: All slain, all dead. 'Romeo is banished!'

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: There is no end, no limit, measure, bound,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: In that word's death; no words can that woe sound.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Where is my father, and my mother, nurse?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Weeping and wailing over Tybalt's corse:

text_entry: Will you go to them? I will bring you thither.

text_entry: Wash they his wounds with tears: mine shall be spent,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: When theirs are dry, for Romeo's banishment.

text_entry: Take up those cords: poor ropes, you are beguiled,

text_entry: Come, cords, come, nurse; I'll to my wedding-bed;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And death, not Romeo, take my maidenhead!

text_entry: Hie to your chamber: I'll find Romeo

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: To comfort you: I wot well where he is.

text_entry: I'll to him; he is hid at Laurence' cell.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O, find him! give this ring to my true knight,

speaker: JULIET

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: SCENE III. Friar Laurence's cell.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Enter FRIAR LAURENCE

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Romeo, come forth; come forth, thou fearful man:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Affliction is enamour'd of thy parts,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And thou art wedded to calamity.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Enter ROMEO

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Father, what news? what is the prince's doom?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What sorrow craves acquaintance at my hand,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: That I yet know not?

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Too familiar

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Is my dear son with such sour company:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: I bring thee tidings of the prince's doom.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What less than dooms-day is the prince's doom?

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: A gentler judgment vanish'd from his lips,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Not body's death, but body's banishment.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Ha, banishment! be merciful, say 'death;'

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: For exile hath more terror in his look,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Much more than death: do not say 'banishment.'

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Hence from Verona art thou banished:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: There is no world without Verona walls,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: But purgatory, torture, hell itself.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Hence-banished is banish'd from the world,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And world's exile is death: then banished,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Is death mis-term'd: calling death banishment,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Thou cutt'st my head off with a golden axe,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And smilest upon the stroke that murders me.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: O deadly sin! O rude unthankfulness!

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thy fault our law calls death; but the kind prince,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Taking thy part, hath rush'd aside the law,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And turn'd that black word death to banishment:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: This is dear mercy, and thou seest it not.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: 'Tis torture, and not mercy: heaven is here,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Where Juliet lives; and every cat and dog

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And little mouse, every unworthy thing,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Live here in heaven and may look on her;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: But Romeo may not: more validity,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: More honourable state, more courtship lives

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: In carrion-flies than Romeo: they my seize

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: On the white wonder of dear Juliet's hand

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And steal immortal blessing from her lips,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Who even in pure and vestal modesty,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Still blush, as thinking their own kisses sin;
