speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: But Romeo may not; he is banished:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Flies may do this, but I from this must fly:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: They are free men, but I am banished.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And say'st thou yet that exile is not death?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Hadst thou no poison mix'd, no sharp-ground knife,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: No sudden mean of death, though ne'er so mean,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: But 'banished' to kill me?--'banished'?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O friar, the damned use that word in hell;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Howlings attend it: how hast thou the heart,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Being a divine, a ghostly confessor,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: A sin-absolver, and my friend profess'd,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: To mangle me with that word 'banished'?

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thou fond mad man, hear me but speak a word.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O, thou wilt speak again of banishment.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: I'll give thee armour to keep off that word:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Adversity's sweet milk, philosophy,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To comfort thee, though thou art banished.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Yet 'banished'? Hang up philosophy!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Unless philosophy can make a Juliet,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Displant a town, reverse a prince's doom,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: It helps not, it prevails not: talk no more.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: O, then I see that madmen have no ears.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: How should they, when that wise men have no eyes?

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Let me dispute with thee of thy estate.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Thou canst not speak of that thou dost not feel:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Wert thou as young as I, Juliet thy love,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: An hour but married, Tybalt murdered,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Doting like me and like me banished,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Then mightst thou speak, then mightst thou tear thy hair,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And fall upon the ground, as I do now,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Taking the measure of an unmade grave.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Knocking within

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Arise; one knocks; good Romeo, hide thyself.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Not I; unless the breath of heartsick groans,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Mist-like, infold me from the search of eyes.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Knocking

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Hark, how they knock! Who's there? Romeo, arise;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thou wilt be taken. Stay awhile! Stand up;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Knocking

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Run to my study. By and by! God's will,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: What simpleness is this! I come, I come!

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Knocking

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Who knocks so hard? whence come you? what's your will?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: [Within]  Let me come in, and you shall know

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: my errand;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I come from Lady Juliet.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Welcome, then.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Enter Nurse

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: O holy friar, O, tell me, holy friar,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Where is my lady's lord, where's Romeo?

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: There on the ground, with his own tears made drunk.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: O, he is even in my mistress' case,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Just in her case! O woful sympathy!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Piteous predicament! Even so lies she,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Stand up, stand up; stand, and you be a man:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: For Juliet's sake, for her sake, rise and stand;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Why should you fall into so deep an O?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Nurse!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Ah sir! ah sir! Well, death's the end of all.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Spakest thou of Juliet? how is it with her?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Doth she not think me an old murderer,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Now I have stain'd the childhood of our joy

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: With blood removed but little from her own?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Where is she? and how doth she? and what says

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: My conceal'd lady to our cancell'd love?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: O, she says nothing, sir, but weeps and weeps;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: And now falls on her bed; and then starts up,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: And Tybalt calls; and then on Romeo cries,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: And then down falls again.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: As if that name,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Shot from the deadly level of a gun,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Did murder her; as that name's cursed hand

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Murder'd her kinsman. O, tell me, friar, tell me,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: In what vile part of this anatomy

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Doth my name lodge? tell me, that I may sack

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: The hateful mansion.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Drawing his sword

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Hold thy desperate hand:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Art thou a man? thy form cries out thou art:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thy tears are womanish; thy wild acts denote

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: The unreasonable fury of a beast:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Unseemly woman in a seeming man!

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Or ill-beseeming beast in seeming both!

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thou hast amazed me: by my holy order,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: I thought thy disposition better temper'd.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Hast thou slain Tybalt? wilt thou slay thyself?

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And stay thy lady too that lives in thee,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: By doing damned hate upon thyself?

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Why rail'st thou on thy birth, the heaven, and earth?

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Since birth, and heaven, and earth, all three do meet

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: In thee at once; which thou at once wouldst lose.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Fie, fie, thou shamest thy shape, thy love, thy wit;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Which, like a usurer, abound'st in all,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And usest none in that true use indeed

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Which should bedeck thy shape, thy love, thy wit:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thy noble shape is but a form of wax,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Digressing from the valour of a man;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thy dear love sworn but hollow perjury,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Killing that love which thou hast vow'd to cherish;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thy wit, that ornament to shape and love,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Misshapen in the conduct of them both,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Like powder in a skitless soldier's flask,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Is set afire by thine own ignorance,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And thou dismember'd with thine own defence.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: What, rouse thee, man! thy Juliet is alive,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: For whose dear sake thou wast but lately dead;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: There art thou happy: Tybalt would kill thee,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: But thou slew'st Tybalt; there are thou happy too:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: The law that threaten'd death becomes thy friend

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And turns it to exile; there art thou happy:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: A pack of blessings lights up upon thy back;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Happiness courts thee in her best array;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: But, like a misbehaved and sullen wench,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thou pout'st upon thy fortune and thy love:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Take heed, take heed, for such die miserable.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Go, get thee to thy love, as was decreed,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Ascend her chamber, hence and comfort her:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: But look thou stay not till the watch be set,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: For then thou canst not pass to Mantua;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Where thou shalt live, till we can find a time

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To blaze your marriage, reconcile your friends,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Beg pardon of the prince, and call thee back

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: With twenty hundred thousand times more joy

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Than thou went'st forth in lamentation.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Go before, nurse: commend me to thy lady;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And bid her hasten all the house to bed,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Which heavy sorrow makes them apt unto:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Romeo is coming.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: O Lord, I could have stay'd here all the night

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: To hear good counsel: O, what learning is!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: My lord, I'll tell my lady you will come.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Do so, and bid my sweet prepare to chide.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Here, sir, a ring she bid me give you, sir:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Hie you, make haste, for it grows very late.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: How well my comfort is revived by this!

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Go hence; good night; and here stands all your state:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Either be gone before the watch be set,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Or by the break of day disguised from hence:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Sojourn in Mantua; I'll find out your man,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And he shall signify from time to time

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Every good hap to you that chances here:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Give me thy hand; 'tis late: farewell; good night.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: But that a joy past joy calls out on me,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: It were a grief, so brief to part with thee: Farewell.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: SCENE IV. A room in Capulet's house.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Enter CAPULET, LADY CAPULET, and PARIS

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Things have fall'n out, sir, so unluckily,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: That we have had no time to move our daughter:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Look you, she loved her kinsman Tybalt dearly,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And so did I:--Well, we were born to die.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: 'Tis very late, she'll not come down to-night:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: I promise you, but for your company,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: I would have been a-bed an hour ago.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: These times of woe afford no time to woo.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Madam, good night: commend me to your daughter.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: I will, and know her mind early to-morrow;

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: To-night she is mew'd up to her heaviness.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Sir Paris, I will make a desperate tender

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Of my child's love: I think she will be ruled

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: In all respects by me; nay, more, I doubt it not.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Wife, go you to her ere you go to bed;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Acquaint her here of my son Paris' love;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And bid her, mark you me, on Wednesday next--

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: But, soft! what day is this?

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Monday, my lord,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Monday! ha, ha! Well, Wednesday is too soon,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: O' Thursday let it be: o' Thursday, tell her,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: She shall be married to this noble earl.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Will you be ready? do you like this haste?

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: We'll keep no great ado,--a friend or two;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: For, hark you, Tybalt being slain so late,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: It may be thought we held him carelessly,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Being our kinsman, if we revel much:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Therefore we'll have some half a dozen friends,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And there an end. But what say you to Thursday?

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: My lord, I would that Thursday were to-morrow.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Well get you gone: o' Thursday be it, then.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Go you to Juliet ere you go to bed,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Prepare her, wife, against this wedding-day.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Farewell, my lord. Light to my chamber, ho!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Afore me! it is so very very late,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: That we may call it early by and by.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Good night.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: SCENE V. Capulet's orchard.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Enter ROMEO and JULIET above, at the window

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Wilt thou be gone? it is not yet near day:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: It was the nightingale, and not the lark,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Nightly she sings on yon pomegranate-tree:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Believe me, love, it was the nightingale.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: It was the lark, the herald of the morn,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: No nightingale: look, love, what envious streaks

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Night's candles are burnt out, and jocund day

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I must be gone and live, or stay and die.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Yon light is not day-light, I know it, I:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: It is some meteor that the sun exhales,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To be to thee this night a torch-bearer,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And light thee on thy way to Mantua:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Therefore stay yet; thou need'st not to be gone.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Let me be ta'en, let me be put to death;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I am content, so thou wilt have it so.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I'll say yon grey is not the morning's eye,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: 'Tis but the pale reflex of Cynthia's brow;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Nor that is not the lark, whose notes do beat

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: The vaulty heaven so high above our heads:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I have more care to stay than will to go:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Come, death, and welcome! Juliet wills it so.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: How is't, my soul? let's talk; it is not day.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: It is, it is: hie hence, be gone, away!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: It is the lark that sings so out of tune,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Straining harsh discords and unpleasing sharps.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Some say the lark makes sweet division;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: This doth not so, for she divideth us:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Some say the lark and loathed toad change eyes,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O, now I would they had changed voices too!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Since arm from arm that voice doth us affray,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Hunting thee hence with hunt's-up to the day,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O, now be gone; more light and light it grows.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: More light and light; more dark and dark our woes!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Enter Nurse, to the chamber

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Madam!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Nurse?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Your lady mother is coming to your chamber:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: The day is broke; be wary, look about.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Then, window, let day in, and let life out.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Farewell, farewell! one kiss, and I'll descend.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: He goeth down

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Art thou gone so? love, lord, ay, husband, friend!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I must hear from thee every day in the hour,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: For in a minute there are many days:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O, by this count I shall be much in years

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Ere I again behold my Romeo!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Farewell!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I will omit no opportunity

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: That may convey my greetings, love, to thee.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O think'st thou we shall ever meet again?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I doubt it not; and all these woes shall serve

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: For sweet discourses in our time to come.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O God, I have an ill-divining soul!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Methinks I see thee, now thou art below,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: As one dead in the bottom of a tomb:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Either my eyesight fails, or thou look'st pale.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And trust me, love, in my eye so do you:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Dry sorrow drinks our blood. Adieu, adieu!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O fortune, fortune! all men call thee fickle:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: If thou art fickle, what dost thou with him.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That is renown'd for faith? Be fickle, fortune;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: For then, I hope, thou wilt not keep him long,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: But send him back.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: [Within]         Ho, daughter! are you up?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Who is't that calls? is it my lady mother?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Is she not down so late, or up so early?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What unaccustom'd cause procures her hither?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Enter LADY CAPULET

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Why, how now, Juliet!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Madam, I am not well.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Evermore weeping for your cousin's death?

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: What, wilt thou wash him from his grave with tears?

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: An if thou couldst, thou couldst not make him live;

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Therefore, have done: some grief shows much of love;

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: But much of grief shows still some want of wit.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Yet let me weep for such a feeling loss.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: So shall you feel the loss, but not the friend

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Which you weep for.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Feeling so the loss,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Cannot choose but ever weep the friend.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Well, girl, thou weep'st not so much for his death,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: As that the villain lives which slaughter'd him.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What villain madam?

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: That same villain, Romeo.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: [Aside]  Villain and he be many miles asunder.--

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: God Pardon him! I do, with all my heart;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And yet no man like he doth grieve my heart.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: That is, because the traitor murderer lives.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Ay, madam, from the reach of these my hands:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Would none but I might venge my cousin's death!

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: We will have vengeance for it, fear thou not:

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Then weep no more. I'll send to one in Mantua,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Where that same banish'd runagate doth live,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Shall give him such an unaccustom'd dram,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: That he shall soon keep Tybalt company:

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: And then, I hope, thou wilt be satisfied.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Indeed, I never shall be satisfied

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: With Romeo, till I behold him--dead--

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Is my poor heart for a kinsman vex'd.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Madam, if you could find out but a man

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To bear a poison, I would temper it;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That Romeo should, upon receipt thereof,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Soon sleep in quiet. O, how my heart abhors

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To hear him named, and cannot come to him.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To wreak the love I bore my cousin

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Upon his body that slaughter'd him!

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Find thou the means, and I'll find such a man.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: But now I'll tell thee joyful tidings, girl.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And joy comes well in such a needy time:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What are they, I beseech your ladyship?

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Well, well, thou hast a careful father, child;

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: One who, to put thee from thy heaviness,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Hath sorted out a sudden day of joy,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: That thou expect'st not nor I look'd not for.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Madam, in happy time, what day is that?

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Marry, my child, early next Thursday morn,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: The gallant, young and noble gentleman,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: The County Paris, at Saint Peter's Church,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Shall happily make thee there a joyful bride.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Now, by Saint Peter's Church and Peter too,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: He shall not make me there a joyful bride.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I wonder at this haste; that I must wed

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Ere he, that should be husband, comes to woo.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I pray you, tell my lord and father, madam,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I will not marry yet; and, when I do, I swear,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: It shall be Romeo, whom you know I hate,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Rather than Paris. These are news indeed!

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Here comes your father; tell him so yourself,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: And see how he will take it at your hands.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Enter CAPULET and Nurse

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: When the sun sets, the air doth drizzle dew;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: But for the sunset of my brother's son

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: It rains downright.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: How now! a conduit, girl? what, still in tears?

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Evermore showering? In one little body

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Thou counterfeit'st a bark, a sea, a wind;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: For still thy eyes, which I may call the sea,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Do ebb and flow with tears; the bark thy body is,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Sailing in this salt flood; the winds, thy sighs;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Who, raging with thy tears, and they with them,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Without a sudden calm, will overset

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Thy tempest-tossed body. How now, wife!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Have you deliver'd to her our decree?

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Ay, sir; but she will none, she gives you thanks.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: I would the fool were married to her grave!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Soft! take me with you, take me with you, wife.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: How! will she none? doth she not give us thanks?

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Is she not proud? doth she not count her blest,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Unworthy as she is, that we have wrought

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: So worthy a gentleman to be her bridegroom?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Not proud, you have; but thankful, that you have:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Proud can I never be of what I hate;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: But thankful even for hate, that is meant love.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: How now, how now, chop-logic! What is this?

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: 'Proud,' and 'I thank you,' and 'I thank you not;'

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And yet 'not proud,' mistress minion, you,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Thank me no thankings, nor, proud me no prouds,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: But fettle your fine joints 'gainst Thursday next,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: To go with Paris to Saint Peter's Church,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Or I will drag thee on a hurdle thither.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Out, you green-sickness carrion! out, you baggage!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: You tallow-face!

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Fie, fie! what, are you mad?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Good father, I beseech you on my knees,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Hear me with patience but to speak a word.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Hang thee, young baggage! disobedient wretch!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: I tell thee what: get thee to church o' Thursday,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Or never after look me in the face:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Speak not, reply not, do not answer me;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: My fingers itch. Wife, we scarce thought us blest

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: That God had lent us but this only child;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: But now I see this one is one too much,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And that we have a curse in having her:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Out on her, hilding!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: God in heaven bless her!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: You are to blame, my lord, to rate her so.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And why, my lady wisdom? hold your tongue,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Good prudence; smatter with your gossips, go.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I speak no treason.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: O, God ye god-den.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: May not one speak?

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Peace, you mumbling fool!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Utter your gravity o'er a gossip's bowl;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: For here we need it not.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: You are too hot.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: God's bread! it makes me mad:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Day, night, hour, tide, time, work, play,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Alone, in company, still my care hath been

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: To have her match'd: and having now provided

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: A gentleman of noble parentage,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Of fair demesnes, youthful, and nobly train'd,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Stuff'd, as they say, with honourable parts,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Proportion'd as one's thought would wish a man;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And then to have a wretched puling fool,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: A whining mammet, in her fortune's tender,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: To answer 'I'll not wed; I cannot love,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: I am too young; I pray you, pardon me.'

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: But, as you will not wed, I'll pardon you:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Graze where you will you shall not house with me:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Look to't, think on't, I do not use to jest.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Thursday is near; lay hand on heart, advise:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: An you be mine, I'll give you to my friend;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And you be not, hang, beg, starve, die in

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: the streets,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: For, by my soul, I'll ne'er acknowledge thee,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Nor what is mine shall never do thee good:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Trust to't, bethink you; I'll not be forsworn.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Is there no pity sitting in the clouds,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That sees into the bottom of my grief?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O, sweet my mother, cast me not away!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Delay this marriage for a month, a week;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or, if you do not, make the bridal bed

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: In that dim monument where Tybalt lies.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Talk not to me, for I'll not speak a word:

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Do as thou wilt, for I have done with thee.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O God!--O nurse, how shall this be prevented?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: My husband is on earth, my faith in heaven;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: How shall that faith return again to earth,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Unless that husband send it me from heaven

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: By leaving earth? comfort me, counsel me.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Alack, alack, that heaven should practise stratagems

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Upon so soft a subject as myself!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What say'st thou? hast thou not a word of joy?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Some comfort, nurse.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Faith, here it is.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Romeo is banish'd; and all the world to nothing,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: That he dares ne'er come back to challenge you;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Or, if he do, it needs must be by stealth.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Then, since the case so stands as now it doth,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I think it best you married with the county.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: O, he's a lovely gentleman!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Romeo's a dishclout to him: an eagle, madam,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Hath not so green, so quick, so fair an eye

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: As Paris hath. Beshrew my very heart,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I think you are happy in this second match,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: For it excels your first: or if it did not,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Your first is dead; or 'twere as good he were,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: As living here and you no use of him.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Speakest thou from thy heart?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: And from my soul too;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Or else beshrew them both.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Amen!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: What?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Well, thou hast comforted me marvellous much.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Go in: and tell my lady I am gone,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Having displeased my father, to Laurence' cell,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To make confession and to be absolved.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Marry, I will; and this is wisely done.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Ancient damnation! O most wicked fiend!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Is it more sin to wish me thus forsworn,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or to dispraise my lord with that same tongue

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Which she hath praised him with above compare

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: So many thousand times? Go, counsellor;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Thou and my bosom henceforth shall be twain.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I'll to the friar, to know his remedy:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: If all else fail, myself have power to die.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: SCENE I. Friar Laurence's cell.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Enter FRIAR LAURENCE and PARIS

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: On Thursday, sir? the time is very short.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: My father Capulet will have it so;

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: And I am nothing slow to slack his haste.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: You say you do not know the lady's mind:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Uneven is the course, I like it not.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Immoderately she weeps for Tybalt's death,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: And therefore have I little talk'd of love;

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: For Venus smiles not in a house of tears.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Now, sir, her father counts it dangerous

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: That she doth give her sorrow so much sway,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: And in his wisdom hastes our marriage,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: To stop the inundation of her tears;

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Which, too much minded by herself alone,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: May be put from her by society:

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Now do you know the reason of this haste.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: [Aside]  I would I knew not why it should be slow'd.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Look, sir, here comes the lady towards my cell.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Enter JULIET

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Happily met, my lady and my wife!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That may be, sir, when I may be a wife.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: That may be must be, love, on Thursday next.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What must be shall be.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: That's a certain text.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Come you to make confession to this father?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To answer that, I should confess to you.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Do not deny to him that you love me.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I will confess to you that I love him.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: So will ye, I am sure, that you love me.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: If I do so, it will be of more price,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Being spoke behind your back, than to your face.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Poor soul, thy face is much abused with tears.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: The tears have got small victory by that;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: For it was bad enough before their spite.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Thou wrong'st it, more than tears, with that report.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That is no slander, sir, which is a truth;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And what I spake, I spake it to my face.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Thy face is mine, and thou hast slander'd it.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: It may be so, for it is not mine own.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Are you at leisure, holy father, now;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or shall I come to you at evening mass?

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: My leisure serves me, pensive daughter, now.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: My lord, we must entreat the time alone.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: God shield I should disturb devotion!

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Juliet, on Thursday early will I rouse ye:

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Till then, adieu; and keep this holy kiss.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O shut the door! and when thou hast done so,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Come weep with me; past hope, past cure, past help!

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Ah, Juliet, I already know thy grief;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: It strains me past the compass of my wits:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: I hear thou must, and nothing may prorogue it,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: On Thursday next be married to this county.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Tell me not, friar, that thou hear'st of this,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Unless thou tell me how I may prevent it:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: If, in thy wisdom, thou canst give no help,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Do thou but call my resolution wise,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And with this knife I'll help it presently.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: God join'd my heart and Romeo's, thou our hands;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And ere this hand, by thee to Romeo seal'd,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Shall be the label to another deed,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or my true heart with treacherous revolt

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Turn to another, this shall slay them both:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Therefore, out of thy long-experienced time,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Give me some present counsel, or, behold,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: 'Twixt my extremes and me this bloody knife

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Shall play the umpire, arbitrating that

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Which the commission of thy years and art

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Could to no issue of true honour bring.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Be not so long to speak; I long to die,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: If what thou speak'st speak not of remedy.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Hold, daughter: I do spy a kind of hope,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Which craves as desperate an execution.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: As that is desperate which we would prevent.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: If, rather than to marry County Paris,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thou hast the strength of will to slay thyself,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Then is it likely thou wilt undertake

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: A thing like death to chide away this shame,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: That copest with death himself to scape from it:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And, if thou darest, I'll give thee remedy.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O, bid me leap, rather than marry Paris,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: From off the battlements of yonder tower;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or walk in thievish ways; or bid me lurk

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Where serpents are; chain me with roaring bears;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or shut me nightly in a charnel-house,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O'er-cover'd quite with dead men's rattling bones,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: With reeky shanks and yellow chapless skulls;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or bid me go into a new-made grave

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And hide me with a dead man in his shroud;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Things that, to hear them told, have made me tremble;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And I will do it without fear or doubt,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To live an unstain'd wife to my sweet love.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Hold, then; go home, be merry, give consent

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To marry Paris: Wednesday is to-morrow:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To-morrow night look that thou lie alone;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Let not thy nurse lie with thee in thy chamber:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Take thou this vial, being then in bed,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And this distilled liquor drink thou off;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: When presently through all thy veins shall run

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: A cold and drowsy humour, for no pulse

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Shall keep his native progress, but surcease:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: No warmth, no breath, shall testify thou livest;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: The roses in thy lips and cheeks shall fade

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To paly ashes, thy eyes' windows fall,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Like death, when he shuts up the day of life;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Each part, deprived of supple government,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Shall, stiff and stark and cold, appear like death:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And in this borrow'd likeness of shrunk death

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thou shalt continue two and forty hours,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And then awake as from a pleasant sleep.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Now, when the bridegroom in the morning comes

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To rouse thee from thy bed, there art thou dead:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Then, as the manner of our country is,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: In thy best robes uncover'd on the bier

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thou shalt be borne to that same ancient vault

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Where all the kindred of the Capulets lie.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: In the mean time, against thou shalt awake,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Shall Romeo by my letters know our drift,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And hither shall he come: and he and I

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Will watch thy waking, and that very night

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Shall Romeo bear thee hence to Mantua.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And this shall free thee from this present shame;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: If no inconstant toy, nor womanish fear,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Abate thy valour in the acting it.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Give me, give me! O, tell not me of fear!

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Hold; get you gone, be strong and prosperous

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: In this resolve: I'll send a friar with speed

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To Mantua, with my letters to thy lord.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Love give me strength! and strength shall help afford.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Farewell, dear father!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: SCENE II. Hall in Capulet's house.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Enter CAPULET, LADY  CAPULET, Nurse, and two Servingmen

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: So many guests invite as here are writ.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Exit First Servant

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Sirrah, go hire me twenty cunning cooks.

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: You shall have none ill, sir; for I'll try if they

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: can lick their fingers.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: How canst thou try them so?

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Marry, sir, 'tis an ill cook that cannot lick his

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: own fingers: therefore he that cannot lick his

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: fingers goes not with me.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Go, be gone.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Exit Second Servant

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: We shall be much unfurnished for this time.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: What, is my daughter gone to Friar Laurence?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Ay, forsooth.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Well, he may chance to do some good on her:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: A peevish self-will'd harlotry it is.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: See where she comes from shrift with merry look.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Enter JULIET

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: How now, my headstrong! where have you been gadding?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Where I have learn'd me to repent the sin

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Of disobedient opposition

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To you and your behests, and am enjoin'd

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: By holy Laurence to fall prostrate here,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And beg your pardon: pardon, I beseech you!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Henceforward I am ever ruled by you.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Send for the county; go tell him of this:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: I'll have this knot knit up to-morrow morning.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I met the youthful lord at Laurence' cell;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And gave him what becomed love I might,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Not step o'er the bounds of modesty.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Why, I am glad on't; this is well: stand up:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: This is as't should be. Let me see the county;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Ay, marry, go, I say, and fetch him hither.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Now, afore God! this reverend holy friar,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Our whole city is much bound to him.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Nurse, will you go with me into my closet,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To help me sort such needful ornaments

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: As you think fit to furnish me to-morrow?

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: No, not till Thursday; there is time enough.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Go, nurse, go with her: we'll to church to-morrow.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Exeunt JULIET and Nurse

speaker: LADY  CAPULET
text_entry: We shall be short in our provision:

speaker: LADY  CAPULET
text_entry: 'Tis now near night.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Tush, I will stir about,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And all things shall be well, I warrant thee, wife:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Go thou to Juliet, help to deck up her;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: I'll not to bed to-night; let me alone;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: I'll play the housewife for this once. What, ho!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: They are all forth. Well, I will walk myself

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: To County Paris, to prepare him up

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Against to-morrow: my heart is wondrous light,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Since this same wayward girl is so reclaim'd.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: SCENE III. Juliet's chamber.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Enter JULIET and Nurse

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Ay, those attires are best: but, gentle nurse,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I pray thee, leave me to my self to-night,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: For I have need of many orisons

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To move the heavens to smile upon my state,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Which, well thou know'st, is cross, and full of sin.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Enter LADY CAPULET

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: What, are you busy, ho? need you my help?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: No, madam; we have cull'd such necessaries

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: As are behoveful for our state to-morrow:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: So please you, let me now be left alone,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And let the nurse this night sit up with you;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: For, I am sure, you have your hands full all,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: In this so sudden business.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Good night:

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Get thee to bed, and rest; for thou hast need.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Exeunt LADY CAPULET and Nurse

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Farewell! God knows when we shall meet again.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I have a faint cold fear thrills through my veins,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That almost freezes up the heat of life:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I'll call them back again to comfort me:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Nurse! What should she do here?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: My dismal scene I needs must act alone.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Come, vial.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What if this mixture do not work at all?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Shall I be married then to-morrow morning?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: No, no: this shall forbid it: lie thou there.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Laying down her dagger

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What if it be a poison, which the friar

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Subtly hath minister'd to have me dead,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Lest in this marriage he should be dishonour'd,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Because he married me before to Romeo?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I fear it is: and yet, methinks, it should not,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: For he hath still been tried a holy man.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: How if, when I am laid into the tomb,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I wake before the time that Romeo

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Come to redeem me? there's a fearful point!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Shall I not, then, be stifled in the vault,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To whose foul mouth no healthsome air breathes in,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And there die strangled ere my Romeo comes?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or, if I live, is it not very like,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: The horrible conceit of death and night,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Together with the terror of the place,--

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: As in a vault, an ancient receptacle,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Where, for these many hundred years, the bones

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Of all my buried ancestors are packed:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Where bloody Tybalt, yet but green in earth,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Lies festering in his shroud; where, as they say,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: At some hours in the night spirits resort;--

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Alack, alack, is it not like that I,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: So early waking, what with loathsome smells,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And shrieks like mandrakes' torn out of the earth,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That living mortals, hearing them, run mad:--

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O, if I wake, shall I not be distraught,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Environed with all these hideous fears?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And madly play with my forefather's joints?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And pluck the mangled Tybalt from his shroud?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And, in this rage, with some great kinsman's bone,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: As with a club, dash out my desperate brains?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O, look! methinks I see my cousin's ghost

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Seeking out Romeo, that did spit his body

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Upon a rapier's point: stay, Tybalt, stay!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Romeo, I come! this do I drink to thee.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: She falls upon her bed, within the curtains

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: SCENE IV. Hall in Capulet's house.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Enter LADY CAPULET and Nurse

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Hold, take these keys, and fetch more spices, nurse.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: They call for dates and quinces in the pastry.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Enter CAPULET

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Come, stir, stir, stir! the second cock hath crow'd,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: The curfew-bell hath rung, 'tis three o'clock:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Look to the baked meats, good Angelica:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Spare not for the cost.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Go, you cot-quean, go,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Get you to bed; faith, You'll be sick to-morrow

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: For this night's watching.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: No, not a whit: what! I have watch'd ere now

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: All night for lesser cause, and ne'er been sick.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Ay, you have been a mouse-hunt in your time;

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: But I will watch you from such watching now.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Exeunt LADY CAPULET and Nurse

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: A jealous hood, a jealous hood!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Enter three or four Servingmen, with spits, logs, and baskets

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Now, fellow,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: What's there?

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Things for the cook, sir; but I know not what.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Make haste, make haste.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Exit First Servant

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Sirrah, fetch drier logs:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Call Peter, he will show thee where they are.

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: I have a head, sir, that will find out logs,

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: And never trouble Peter for the matter.

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Mass, and well said; a merry whoreson, ha!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Thou shalt be logger-head. Good faith, 'tis day:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: The county will be here with music straight,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: For so he said he would: I hear him near.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Music within

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Nurse! Wife! What, ho! What, nurse, I say!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Re-enter Nurse

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Go waken Juliet, go and trim her up;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: I'll go and chat with Paris: hie, make haste,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Make haste; the bridegroom he is come already:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Make haste, I say.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: SCENE V. Juliet's chamber.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Enter Nurse

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Mistress! what, mistress! Juliet! fast, I warrant her, she:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Why, lamb! why, lady! fie, you slug-a-bed!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Why, love, I say! madam! sweet-heart! why, bride!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: What, not a word? you take your pennyworths now;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Sleep for a week; for the next night, I warrant,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: The County Paris hath set up his rest,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: That you shall rest but little. God forgive me,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Marry, and amen, how sound is she asleep!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I must needs wake her. Madam, madam, madam!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Ay, let the county take you in your bed;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: He'll fright you up, i' faith. Will it not be?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Undraws the curtains

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: What, dress'd! and in your clothes! and down again!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: I must needs wake you; Lady! lady! lady!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Alas, alas! Help, help! my lady's dead!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: O, well-a-day, that ever I was born!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Some aqua vitae, ho! My lord! my lady!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Enter LADY CAPULET

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: What noise is here?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: O lamentable day!

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: What is the matter?

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Look, look! O heavy day!

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: O me, O me! My child, my only life,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Revive, look up, or I will die with thee!

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Help, help! Call help.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Enter CAPULET

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: For shame, bring Juliet forth; her lord is come.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: She's dead, deceased, she's dead; alack the day!

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Alack the day, she's dead, she's dead, she's dead!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Ha! let me see her: out, alas! she's cold:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Her blood is settled, and her joints are stiff;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Life and these lips have long been separated:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Death lies on her like an untimely frost

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Upon the sweetest flower of all the field.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: O lamentable day!

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: O woful time!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Death, that hath ta'en her hence to make me wail,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Ties up my tongue, and will not let me speak.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Enter FRIAR LAURENCE and PARIS, with Musicians

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Come, is the bride ready to go to church?

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Ready to go, but never to return.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: O son! the night before thy wedding-day

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Hath Death lain with thy wife. There she lies,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Flower as she was, deflowered by him.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Death is my son-in-law, Death is my heir;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: My daughter he hath wedded: I will die,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And leave him all; life, living, all is Death's.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Have I thought long to see this morning's face,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: And doth it give me such a sight as this?

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day!

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Most miserable hour that e'er time saw

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: In lasting labour of his pilgrimage!

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: But one, poor one, one poor and loving child,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: But one thing to rejoice and solace in,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: And cruel death hath catch'd it from my sight!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: O woe! O woful, woful, woful day!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Most lamentable day, most woful day,

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: That ever, ever, I did yet behold!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: O day! O day! O day! O hateful day!

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Never was seen so black a day as this:

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: O woful day, O woful day!

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Beguiled, divorced, wronged, spited, slain!

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Most detestable death, by thee beguil'd,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: By cruel cruel thee quite overthrown!

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: O love! O life! not life, but love in death!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Despised, distressed, hated, martyr'd, kill'd!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Uncomfortable time, why camest thou now

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: To murder, murder our solemnity?

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: O child! O child! my soul, and not my child!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Dead art thou! Alack! my child is dead;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And with my child my joys are buried.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Peace, ho, for shame! confusion's cure lives not

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: In these confusions. Heaven and yourself

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Had part in this fair maid; now heaven hath all,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And all the better is it for the maid:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Your part in her you could not keep from death,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: But heaven keeps his part in eternal life.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: The most you sought was her promotion;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: For 'twas your heaven she should be advanced:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And weep ye now, seeing she is advanced

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Above the clouds, as high as heaven itself?

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: O, in this love, you love your child so ill,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: That you run mad, seeing that she is well:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: She's not well married that lives married long;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: But she's best married that dies married young.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Dry up your tears, and stick your rosemary

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: On this fair corse; and, as the custom is,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: In all her best array bear her to church:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: For though fond nature bids us an lament,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Yet nature's tears are reason's merriment.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: All things that we ordained festival,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Turn from their office to black funeral;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Our instruments to melancholy bells,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Our wedding cheer to a sad burial feast,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Our solemn hymns to sullen dirges change,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Our bridal flowers serve for a buried corse,

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And all things change them to the contrary.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Sir, go you in; and, madam, go with him;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And go, Sir Paris; every one prepare

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To follow this fair corse unto her grave:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: The heavens do lour upon you for some ill;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Move them no more by crossing their high will.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Exeunt CAPULET, LADY CAPULET, PARIS, and FRIAR LAURENCE

speaker: First Musician
text_entry: Faith, we may put up our pipes, and be gone.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Honest goodfellows, ah, put up, put up;

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: For, well you know, this is a pitiful case.

speaker: Nurse
text_entry: Exit

speaker: First Musician
text_entry: Ay, by my troth, the case may be amended.

speaker: First Musician
text_entry: Enter PETER

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Musicians, O, musicians, 'Heart's ease, Heart's

speaker: PETER
text_entry: ease:' O, an you will have me live, play 'Heart's ease.'

speaker: First Musician
text_entry: Why 'Heart's ease?'

speaker: PETER
text_entry: O, musicians, because my heart itself plays 'My

speaker: PETER
text_entry: heart is full of woe:' O, play me some merry dump,

speaker: PETER
text_entry: to comfort me.

speaker: First Musician
text_entry: Not a dump we; 'tis no time to play now.

speaker: PETER
text_entry: You will not, then?

speaker: First Musician
text_entry: No.

speaker: PETER
text_entry: I will then give it you soundly.

speaker: First Musician
text_entry: What will you give us?

speaker: PETER
text_entry: No money, on my faith, but the gleek;

speaker: PETER
text_entry: I will give you the minstrel.

speaker: First Musician
text_entry: Then I will give you the serving-creature.

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Then will I lay the serving-creature's dagger on

speaker: PETER
text_entry: your pate. I will carry no crotchets: I'll re you,

speaker: PETER
text_entry: I'll fa you; do you note me?

speaker: First Musician
text_entry: An you re us and fa us, you note us.

speaker: Second Musician
text_entry: Pray you, put up your dagger, and put out your wit.

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Then have at you with my wit! I will dry-beat you

speaker: PETER
text_entry: with an iron wit, and put up my iron dagger. Answer

speaker: PETER
text_entry: me like men:

speaker: PETER
text_entry: 'When griping grief the heart doth wound,

speaker: PETER
text_entry: And doleful dumps the mind oppress,

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Then music with her silver sound'--

speaker: PETER
text_entry: why 'silver sound'? why 'music with her silver

speaker: PETER
text_entry: sound'? What say you, Simon Catling?

speaker: Musician
text_entry: Marry, sir, because silver hath a sweet sound.

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Pretty! What say you, Hugh Rebeck?

speaker: Second Musician
text_entry: I say 'silver sound,' because musicians sound for silver.

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Pretty too! What say you, James Soundpost?

speaker: Third Musician
text_entry: Faith, I know not what to say.

speaker: PETER
text_entry: O, I cry you mercy; you are the singer: I will say

speaker: PETER
text_entry: for you. It is 'music with her silver sound,'

speaker: PETER
text_entry: because musicians have no gold for sounding:

speaker: PETER
text_entry: 'Then music with her silver sound

speaker: PETER
text_entry: With speedy help doth lend redress.'

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: First Musician
text_entry: What a pestilent knave is this same!

speaker: Second Musician
text_entry: Hang him, Jack! Come, we'll in here; tarry for the

speaker: Second Musician
text_entry: mourners, and stay dinner.

speaker: Second Musician
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Second Musician
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: Second Musician
text_entry: SCENE I. Mantua. A street.

speaker: Second Musician
text_entry: Enter ROMEO

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: If I may trust the flattering truth of sleep,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: My dreams presage some joyful news at hand:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: My bosom's lord sits lightly in his throne;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And all this day an unaccustom'd spirit

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Lifts me above the ground with cheerful thoughts.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I dreamt my lady came and found me dead--

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Strange dream, that gives a dead man leave

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: to think!--

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And breathed such life with kisses in my lips,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: That I revived, and was an emperor.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Ah me! how sweet is love itself possess'd,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: When but love's shadows are so rich in joy!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Enter BALTHASAR, booted

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: News from Verona!--How now, Balthasar!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Dost thou not bring me letters from the friar?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: How doth my lady? Is my father well?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: How fares my Juliet? that I ask again;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: For nothing can be ill, if she be well.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Then she is well, and nothing can be ill:

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Her body sleeps in Capel's monument,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: And her immortal part with angels lives.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: I saw her laid low in her kindred's vault,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: And presently took post to tell it you:

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: O, pardon me for bringing these ill news,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Since you did leave it for my office, sir.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Is it even so? then I defy you, stars!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Thou know'st my lodging: get me ink and paper,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And hire post-horses; I will hence to-night.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: I do beseech you, sir, have patience:

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Your looks are pale and wild, and do import

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Some misadventure.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Tush, thou art deceived:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Leave me, and do the thing I bid thee do.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Hast thou no letters to me from the friar?

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: No, my good lord.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: No matter: get thee gone,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And hire those horses; I'll be with thee straight.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Exit BALTHASAR

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Well, Juliet, I will lie with thee to-night.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Let's see for means: O mischief, thou art swift

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: To enter in the thoughts of desperate men!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I do remember an apothecary,--

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And hereabouts he dwells,--which late I noted

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: In tatter'd weeds, with overwhelming brows,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Culling of simples; meagre were his looks,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Sharp misery had worn him to the bones:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And in his needy shop a tortoise hung,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: An alligator stuff'd, and other skins

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Of ill-shaped fishes; and about his shelves

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: A beggarly account of empty boxes,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Green earthen pots, bladders and musty seeds,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Remnants of packthread and old cakes of roses,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Were thinly scatter'd, to make up a show.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Noting this penury, to myself I said

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: 'An if a man did need a poison now,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Whose sale is present death in Mantua,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Here lives a caitiff wretch would sell it him.'

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O, this same thought did but forerun my need;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And this same needy man must sell it me.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: As I remember, this should be the house.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Being holiday, the beggar's shop is shut.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What, ho! apothecary!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Enter Apothecary

speaker: Apothecary
text_entry: Who calls so loud?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Come hither, man. I see that thou art poor:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Hold, there is forty ducats: let me have

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: A dram of poison, such soon-speeding gear

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: As will disperse itself through all the veins

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: That the life-weary taker may fall dead

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And that the trunk may be discharged of breath

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: As violently as hasty powder fired

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Doth hurry from the fatal cannon's womb.

speaker: Apothecary
text_entry: Such mortal drugs I have; but Mantua's law

speaker: Apothecary
text_entry: Is death to any he that utters them.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Art thou so bare and full of wretchedness,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And fear'st to die? famine is in thy cheeks,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Need and oppression starveth in thine eyes,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Contempt and beggary hangs upon thy back;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: The world is not thy friend nor the world's law;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: The world affords no law to make thee rich;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Then be not poor, but break it, and take this.

speaker: Apothecary
text_entry: My poverty, but not my will, consents.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I pay thy poverty, and not thy will.

speaker: Apothecary
text_entry: Put this in any liquid thing you will,

speaker: Apothecary
text_entry: And drink it off; and, if you had the strength

speaker: Apothecary
text_entry: Of twenty men, it would dispatch you straight.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: There is thy gold, worse poison to men's souls,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Doing more murders in this loathsome world,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Than these poor compounds that thou mayst not sell.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I sell thee poison; thou hast sold me none.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Farewell: buy food, and get thyself in flesh.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Come, cordial and not poison, go with me

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: To Juliet's grave; for there must I use thee.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: SCENE II. Friar Laurence's cell.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Enter FRIAR JOHN

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
text_entry: Holy Franciscan friar! brother, ho!

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
text_entry: Enter FRIAR LAURENCE

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: This same should be the voice of Friar John.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Welcome from Mantua: what says Romeo?

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Or, if his mind be writ, give me his letter.

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
text_entry: Going to find a bare-foot brother out

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
text_entry: One of our order, to associate me,

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
text_entry: Here in this city visiting the sick,

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
text_entry: And finding him, the searchers of the town,

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
text_entry: Suspecting that we both were in a house

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
text_entry: Where the infectious pestilence did reign,

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
text_entry: Seal'd up the doors, and would not let us forth;

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
text_entry: So that my speed to Mantua there was stay'd.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Who bare my letter, then, to Romeo?

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
text_entry: I could not send it,--here it is again,--

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
text_entry: Nor get a messenger to bring it thee,

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
text_entry: So fearful were they of infection.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Unhappy fortune! by my brotherhood,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: The letter was not nice but full of charge

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Of dear import, and the neglecting it

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: May do much danger. Friar John, go hence;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Get me an iron crow, and bring it straight

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Unto my cell.

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
text_entry: Brother, I'll go and bring it thee.

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
text_entry: Exit

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Now must I to the monument alone;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Within three hours will fair Juliet wake:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: She will beshrew me much that Romeo

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Hath had no notice of these accidents;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: But I will write again to Mantua,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And keep her at my cell till Romeo come;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Poor living corse, closed in a dead man's tomb!

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: SCENE III. A churchyard; in it a tomb belonging to the Capulets.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Enter PARIS, and his Page bearing flowers and a torch

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Give me thy torch, boy: hence, and stand aloof:

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Yet put it out, for I would not be seen.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Under yond yew-trees lay thee all along,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Holding thine ear close to the hollow ground;

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: So shall no foot upon the churchyard tread,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Being loose, unfirm, with digging up of graves,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: But thou shalt hear it: whistle then to me,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: As signal that thou hear'st something approach.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Give me those flowers. Do as I bid thee, go.

speaker: PAGE
text_entry: [Aside]  I am almost afraid to stand alone

speaker: PAGE
text_entry: Here in the churchyard; yet I will adventure.

speaker: PAGE
text_entry: Retires

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Sweet flower, with flowers thy bridal bed I strew,--

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: O woe! thy canopy is dust and stones;--

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Which with sweet water nightly I will dew,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Or, wanting that, with tears distill'd by moans:

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: The obsequies that I for thee will keep

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Nightly shall be to strew thy grave and weep.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: The Page whistles

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: The boy gives warning something doth approach.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: What cursed foot wanders this way to-night,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: To cross my obsequies and true love's rite?

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: What with a torch! muffle me, night, awhile.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Retires

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Enter ROMEO and BALTHASAR, with a torch, mattock,  and c

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Give me that mattock and the wrenching iron.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Hold, take this letter; early in the morning

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: See thou deliver it to my lord and father.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Give me the light: upon thy life, I charge thee,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Whate'er thou hear'st or seest, stand all aloof,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And do not interrupt me in my course.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Why I descend into this bed of death,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Is partly to behold my lady's face;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: But chiefly to take thence from her dead finger

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: A precious ring, a ring that I must use

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: In dear employment: therefore hence, be gone:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: But if thou, jealous, dost return to pry

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: In what I further shall intend to do,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: By heaven, I will tear thee joint by joint

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And strew this hungry churchyard with thy limbs:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: The time and my intents are savage-wild,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: More fierce and more inexorable far

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Than empty tigers or the roaring sea.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: I will be gone, sir, and not trouble you.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: So shalt thou show me friendship. Take thou that:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Live, and be prosperous: and farewell, good fellow.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: [Aside]  For all this same, I'll hide me hereabout:

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: His looks I fear, and his intents I doubt.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Retires

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Thou detestable maw, thou womb of death,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Gorged with the dearest morsel of the earth,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Thus I enforce thy rotten jaws to open,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And, in despite, I'll cram thee with more food!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Opens the tomb

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: This is that banish'd haughty Montague,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: That murder'd my love's cousin, with which grief,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: It is supposed, the fair creature died;

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: And here is come to do some villanous shame

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: To the dead bodies: I will apprehend him.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Comes forward

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Stop thy unhallow'd toil, vile Montague!

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Can vengeance be pursued further than death?

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Condemned villain, I do apprehend thee:

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Obey, and go with me; for thou must die.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I must indeed; and therefore came I hither.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Good gentle youth, tempt not a desperate man;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Fly hence, and leave me: think upon these gone;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Let them affright thee. I beseech thee, youth,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Put not another sin upon my head,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: By urging me to fury: O, be gone!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: By heaven, I love thee better than myself;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: For I come hither arm'd against myself:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Stay not, be gone; live, and hereafter say,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: A madman's mercy bade thee run away.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: I do defy thy conjurations,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: And apprehend thee for a felon here.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Wilt thou provoke me? then have at thee, boy!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: They fight

speaker: PAGE
text_entry: O Lord, they fight! I will go call the watch.

speaker: PAGE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: O, I am slain!

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Falls

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: If thou be merciful,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Open the tomb, lay me with Juliet.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Dies

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: In faith, I will. Let me peruse this face.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Mercutio's kinsman, noble County Paris!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: What said my man, when my betossed soul

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Did not attend him as we rode? I think

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: He told me Paris should have married Juliet:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Said he not so? or did I dream it so?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Or am I mad, hearing him talk of Juliet,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: To think it was so? O, give me thy hand,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: One writ with me in sour misfortune's book!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I'll bury thee in a triumphant grave;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: A grave? O no! a lantern, slaughter'd youth,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: For here lies Juliet, and her beauty makes

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: This vault a feasting presence full of light.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Death, lie thou there, by a dead man interr'd.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Laying PARIS in the tomb

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: How oft when men are at the point of death

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Have they been merry! which their keepers call

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: A lightning before death: O, how may I

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Call this a lightning? O my love! my wife!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Death, that hath suck'd the honey of thy breath,

speaker: ROMEO
