text_entry: Hath had no power yet upon thy beauty:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Thou art not conquer'd; beauty's ensign yet

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Is crimson in thy lips and in thy cheeks,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And death's pale flag is not advanced there.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Tybalt, liest thou there in thy bloody sheet?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O, what more favour can I do to thee,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Than with that hand that cut thy youth in twain

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: To sunder his that was thine enemy?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Forgive me, cousin! Ah, dear Juliet,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Why art thou yet so fair? shall I believe

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: That unsubstantial death is amorous,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And that the lean abhorred monster keeps

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Thee here in dark to be his paramour?

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: For fear of that, I still will stay with thee;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And never from this palace of dim night

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Depart again: here, here will I remain

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: With worms that are thy chamber-maids; O, here

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Will I set up my everlasting rest,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And shake the yoke of inauspicious stars

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: From this world-wearied flesh. Eyes, look your last!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Arms, take your last embrace! and, lips, O you

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: The doors of breath, seal with a righteous kiss

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: A dateless bargain to engrossing death!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Come, bitter conduct, come, unsavoury guide!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Thou desperate pilot, now at once run on

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: The dashing rocks thy sea-sick weary bark!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Here's to my love!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Drinks

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O true apothecary!

speaker: ROMEO

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Dies

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Enter, at the other end of the churchyard, FRIAR LAURENCE, with a lantern, crow, and spade

text_entry: Saint Francis be my speed! how oft to-night

text_entry: Have my old feet stumbled at graves! Who's there?

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Here's one, a friend, and one that knows you well.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Bliss be upon you! Tell me, good my friend,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: What torch is yond, that vainly lends his light

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To grubs and eyeless skulls? as I discern,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: It burneth in the Capel's monument.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: It doth so, holy sir; and there's my master,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: One that you love.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Who is it?

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Romeo.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: How long hath he been there?

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Full half an hour.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Go with me to the vault.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: I dare not, sir

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: My master knows not but I am gone hence;

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: And fearfully did menace me with death,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: If I did stay to look on his intents.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Stay, then; I'll go alone. Fear comes upon me:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: O, much I fear some ill unlucky thing.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: As I did sleep under this yew-tree here,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: I dreamt my master and another fought,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: And that my master slew him.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Romeo!

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Advances

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Alack, alack, what blood is this, which stains

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: The stony entrance of this sepulchre?

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: What mean these masterless and gory swords

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To lie discolour'd by this place of peace?

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Enters the tomb

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Romeo! O, pale! Who else? what, Paris too?

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And steep'd in blood? Ah, what an unkind hour

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Is guilty of this lamentable chance!

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: The lady stirs.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: JULIET wakes

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O comfortable friar! where is my lord?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I do remember well where I should be,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And there I am. Where is my Romeo?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Noise within

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: I hear some noise. Lady, come from that nest

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Of death, contagion, and unnatural sleep:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: A greater power than we can contradict

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Hath thwarted our intents. Come, come away.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thy husband in thy bosom there lies dead;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And Paris too. Come, I'll dispose of thee

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Among a sisterhood of holy nuns:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Stay not to question, for the watch is coming;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Come, go, good Juliet,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Noise again

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: I dare no longer stay.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Go, get thee hence, for I will not away.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Exit FRIAR LAURENCE

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What's here? a cup, closed in my true love's hand?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Poison, I see, hath been his timeless end:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O churl! drunk all, and left no friendly drop

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To help me after? I will kiss thy lips;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Haply some poison yet doth hang on them,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To make die with a restorative.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Kisses him

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Thy lips are warm.

text_entry: [Within]  Lead, boy: which way?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: This is thy sheath;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Stabs herself

text_entry: there rust, and let me die.

text_entry: Enter Watch, with the Page of PARIS

text_entry: This is the place; there, where the torch doth burn.

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: The ground is bloody; search about the churchyard:

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Go, some of you, whoe'er you find attach.

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Pitiful sight! here lies the county slain,

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: And Juliet bleeding, warm, and newly dead,

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Who here hath lain these two days buried.

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Go, tell the prince: run to the Capulets:

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Raise up the Montagues: some others search:

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: We see the ground whereon these woes do lie;

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: But the true ground of all these piteous woes

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: We cannot without circumstance descry.

speaker: First Watchman

text_entry: Here's Romeo's man; we found him in the churchyard.

text_entry: Hold him in safety, till the prince come hither.

speaker: First Watchman

speaker: Third Watchman
text_entry: Here is a friar, that trembles, sighs and weeps:

speaker: Third Watchman
text_entry: We took this mattock and this spade from him,

speaker: Third Watchman
text_entry: As he was coming from this churchyard side.

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: A great suspicion: stay the friar too.

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Enter the PRINCE and Attendants

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: What misadventure is so early up,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: That calls our person from our morning's rest?

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Enter CAPULET, LADY CAPULET, and others

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: What should it be, that they so shriek abroad?

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Some Juliet, and some Paris; and all run,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: With open outcry toward our monument.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: What fear is this which startles in our ears?

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Sovereign, here lies the County Paris slain;

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: And Romeo dead; and Juliet, dead before,

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Warm and new kill'd.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Search, seek, and know how this foul murder comes.

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Here is a friar, and slaughter'd Romeo's man;

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: With instruments upon them, fit to open

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: These dead men's tombs.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: O heavens! O wife, look how our daughter bleeds!

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: This dagger hath mista'en--for, lo, his house

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Is empty on the back of Montague,--

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: And it mis-sheathed in my daughter's bosom!

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: O me! this sight of death is as a bell,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: That warns my old age to a sepulchre.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Enter MONTAGUE and others

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Come, Montague; for thou art early up,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: To see thy son and heir more early down.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Alas, my liege, my wife is dead to-night;

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Grief of my son's exile hath stopp'd her breath:

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: What further woe conspires against mine age?

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Look, and thou shalt see.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: O thou untaught! what manners is in this?

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: To press before thy father to a grave?

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Seal up the mouth of outrage for a while,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Till we can clear these ambiguities,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: And know their spring, their head, their

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: true descent;

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: And then will I be general of your woes,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: And lead you even to death: meantime forbear,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: And let mischance be slave to patience.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Bring forth the parties of suspicion.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: I am the greatest, able to do least,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Yet most suspected, as the time and place

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Doth make against me of this direful murder;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And here I stand, both to impeach and purge

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Myself condemned and myself excused.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Then say at once what thou dost know in this.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: I will be brief, for my short date of breath

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Is not so long as is a tedious tale.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Romeo, there dead, was husband to that Juliet;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And she, there dead, that Romeo's faithful wife:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: I married them; and their stol'n marriage-day

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Was Tybalt's dooms-day, whose untimely death

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Banish'd the new-made bridegroom from the city,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: For whom, and not for Tybalt, Juliet pined.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: You, to remove that siege of grief from her,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Betroth'd and would have married her perforce

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To County Paris: then comes she to me,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And, with wild looks, bid me devise some mean

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To rid her from this second marriage,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Or in my cell there would she kill herself.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Then gave I her, so tutor'd by my art,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: A sleeping potion; which so took effect

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: As I intended, for it wrought on her

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: The form of death: meantime I writ to Romeo,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: That he should hither come as this dire night,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To help to take her from her borrow'd grave,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Being the time the potion's force should cease.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: But he which bore my letter, Friar John,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Was stay'd by accident, and yesternight

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Return'd my letter back. Then all alone

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: At the prefixed hour of her waking,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Came I to take her from her kindred's vault;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Meaning to keep her closely at my cell,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Till I conveniently could send to Romeo:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: But when I came, some minute ere the time

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Of her awaking, here untimely lay

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: The noble Paris and true Romeo dead.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: She wakes; and I entreated her come forth,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And bear this work of heaven with patience:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: But then a noise did scare me from the tomb;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And she, too desperate, would not go with me,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: But, as it seems, did violence on herself.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: All this I know; and to the marriage

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Her nurse is privy: and, if aught in this

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Miscarried by my fault, let my old life

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Be sacrificed, some hour before his time,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Unto the rigour of severest law.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: We still have known thee for a holy man.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Where's Romeo's man? what can he say in this?

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: I brought my master news of Juliet's death;

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: And then in post he came from Mantua

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: To this same place, to this same monument.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: This letter he early bid me give his father,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: And threatened me with death, going in the vault,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: I departed not and left him there.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Give me the letter; I will look on it.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Where is the county's page, that raised the watch?

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Sirrah, what made your master in this place?

speaker: PAGE
text_entry: He came with flowers to strew his lady's grave;

speaker: PAGE
text_entry: And bid me stand aloof, and so I did:

speaker: PAGE
text_entry: Anon comes one with light to ope the tomb;

speaker: PAGE
text_entry: And by and by my master drew on him;

speaker: PAGE
text_entry: And then I ran away to call the watch.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: This letter doth make good the friar's words,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Their course of love, the tidings of her death:

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: And here he writes that he did buy a poison

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Of a poor 'pothecary, and therewithal

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Came to this vault to die, and lie with Juliet.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Where be these enemies? Capulet! Montague!

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: See, what a scourge is laid upon your hate,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: That heaven finds means to kill your joys with love.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: And I for winking at your discords too

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Have lost a brace of kinsmen: all are punish'd.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: O brother Montague, give me thy hand:

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: This is my daughter's jointure, for no more

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Can I demand.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: But I can give thee more:

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: For I will raise her statue in pure gold;

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: That while Verona by that name is known,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: There shall no figure at such rate be set

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: As that of true and faithful Juliet.

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: As rich shall Romeo's by his lady's lie;

speaker: CAPULET
text_entry: Poor sacrifices of our enmity!

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: A glooming peace this morning with it brings;

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: The sun, for sorrow, will not show his head:

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Go hence, to have more talk of these sad things;

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Some shall be pardon'd, and some punished:

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: For never was a story of more woe

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Than this of Juliet and her Romeo.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Exeunt
